{"uri": "8233276797", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "10:07:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T10:07:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T10:07:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "http://www.hiiraan.com/news4/2024/july/197150/yemen_s_houthis_claim_responsibility_for_deadly_tel_aviv_drone_attack.aspx", "title": "Yemen's Houthis claim responsibility for deadly Tel Aviv drone attack", "body": "Friday July 19, 2024\n\nEmergency personnel walk outside a US Embassy branch office situated near the site of an explosion in Tel Aviv, Israel on July 19, 2024. Ricardo Moraes/Reuters\n\nYemen's Houthi militia on Friday claimed responsibility for an overnight drone attack in Tel Aviv, which killed one person and wounded 10 others.\n\nA statement from the rebels, who have carried out dozens of attacks against Red Sea shipping since the start of the Gaza war in October, their \"UAV force\" - referring to unmanned aeriel vehicles - attacked \"one of the important targets in the occupied Jaffa region, what is now called Israeli Tel Aviv.\"\n\nIn a televised speech Friday, Houthi spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nAn initial Israeli military investigation into the attack found an explosive-laden drone had been identified, but not engaged by air defences due to human error, according to Israeli media.\n\nTel Aviv in heightened alert state\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nThe Israeli military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures, however the mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nThe Israeli military said it was investigating an apparent drone attack that hit central Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday but which did not trigger the air raid sirens.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and said the circumstances were being investigated.\n\nFour people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries and four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, the hospital said.\n\nFootage from the site showed an apparent impact on a building located close to US embassy premises in Tel Aviv.\n\nBroken glass could be seen strewn across the city pavements as crowds of onlookers gathered nearby. The site was sealed off by police tape.\n\nThe explosion occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\n\"An initial inquiry indicates that the explosion in Tel Aviv was caused by the falling of an aerial target, and no sirens were activated. The incident is under thorough review,\" the military said in a statement.\n\nHezbollah and the Houthis have stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians after Israel invaded the Gaza Strip following an attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel.", "source": {"uri": "hiiraan.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hiiraan Online"}, Broken glass could be seen strewn across the city pavements as crowds of onlookers gathered nearby. The site was sealed off by police tape.\n\nIsraeli media said fragments from an drone of a kind widely used by Iranian-backed militia groups in the region had been recovered nearby.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians.\n\nIsrael invaded the Gaza Strip {"uri": "8233386623", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:15:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:15:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:15:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/world/middle-east/2024-07-19-iran-backed-houthis-claim-drone-attack-on-tel-aviv/", "title": "Iran-backed Houthis claim drone attack on Tel Aviv", "body": "Tel Aviv -- A long-range Iranian-made drone hit the centre of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday, in an attack claimed by the Yemen-based Houthi terror group that killed one man and slightly wounded four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\nChief spokesperson Rear Adm Daniel Hagari said the military assessed that the drone was an upgraded Iranian-made Samad-3 model.\n\n\"Our estimation is that it arrived from Yemen to Tel Aviv,\" he told a briefing with journalists.\n\nHe also said there were \"increasing signs\" that Mohammed Deif, head of the military wing of Hamas, had been killed in an Israeli air strike last week.\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv, which comes ahead of a visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu next week, is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian terror group Hamas.\n\nAn Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the drone was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" the military official told journalists after the strike.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures. The mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesperson for Yemen's Houthi militants, which like Hezbollah are aligned with Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa\", which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars.\n\n\"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50-year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and four people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries. Four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, health services said.\n\nFootage from the site showed an apparent impact on a building located close to US embassy premises in Tel Aviv.\n\nIsraeli media said fragments from a drone of a kind widely used by Iranian-backed militia groups in the region had been recovered nearby.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians, after Israel invaded the Gaza Strip following last year's attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel.\n\nHamas-led fighters stormed Israeli towns on October 7, killing about 1,200 people and taking more than 250 hostages back to Gaza, according to Israeli tallies. Since then, more than 38,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's assault on the Gaza Strip, according to Gazan health authorities.", "source": {"uri": "businesslive.co.za", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8233053823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "07:43:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T07:43:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T07:42:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/news/conflict/houthis-claim-deadly-drone-attack-on-israels-tel-aviv-c-15409685", "title": "Houthis claim deadly drone attack on Israel's Tel Aviv", "body": "Houthis claim deadly drone attack on Israel's Tel AvivRami AmichayReutersFri, 19 July 2024 3:39PM\n\nA large, long-range drone has hit the centre of Tel Aviv in an attack claimed by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia that killed one man and slightly wounding four others, the Israeli military and emergency services say.\n\nThe explosion early on Friday, which did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV (unmanned aerial vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" an Israeli military official told journalists after the strike.\n\nThe official did not confirm the claim from the Yemen-based Houthi militia but said: \"We're not ruling out any possibilities right now.\"\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nThe Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the drone was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but it had not ordered new civil defence measures.\n\nHowever, the mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthi militants, which like Hezbollah are backed by Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa\", which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars.\n\n\"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and said the circumstances were being investigated.\n\nFour people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries and four others were treated for shock.\n\nAll of them were later released, the hospital said.\n\nFootage from the site showed an apparent impact on a building located close to U.S. embassy premises in Tel Aviv.\n\nIsraeli media said fragments from a drone of a kind widely used by Iranian-backed militia groups had been recovered nearby.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians.\n\nIsrael invaded the Gaza Strip following an attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel in October 2023.\n\nGet the latest news AFP\n\nA large, long-range drone hit the centre of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday, in an attack claimed by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia that killed one man and slightly wounding four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\n\"An initial inquiry indicates that the explosion in Tel Aviv was caused by the falling of an aerial target, and no sirens were activated. The incident is under thorough review,\" the military said in a statement.\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nThe attack is also likely to ratchet up tensions between Israel and Iran, the Houthis' main sponsor, analysts said.\n\nSince the start of the war in Gaza, the US has worked hard to prevent the conflict from evolving into a regional all-out war or causing a direct confrontation between the \"Islamic Republic\" and the Jewish state.\n\nIsrael said air patrols had been increased to protect its airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures, however the mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthi militants said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel as part of its activities aimed at showing solidarity with Hamas in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, Houthi spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and said the circumstances were being investigated.\n\nFour people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries and four others were treated for shock. The incident is under thorough review,\" the military said in a statement.\n\nIt was not clear how a relatively slow-moving drone evaded extensive Israeli air defenses. In April when Iran fired nearly 350 drones and missiles, 99% were intercepted and no real damage was reported.\n\nIran's Tasnim website affiliated with the Revolutionary Guard published the news of the attack, quoting Houthi officials praising the operation, and saying the \"one Zionist was killed and eight others injured.\" Other Iranian government-controlled media relayed the news insisting that the Houthis were able to inflict \"great damage\" on Tel Aviv.\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nIt said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures, however the mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthi militants, which like Hezbollah are backed by Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50-year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and said the circumstances were being investigated.\n\nFour people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries and four others were treated for shock. {"uri": "8233220250", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "09:32:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T09:32:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T09:32:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://middle-east-online.com/en/tel-aviv-hit-drone-attack-claimed-yemen%E2%80%99s-houthis", "title": "Tel Aviv hit by drone attack claimed by Yemen's Houthis | MEO", "body": "TEL AVIV - A long-range Iranian-made drone hit the centre of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday, in an attack claimed by the Yemen-based Houthi militia that killed one man and slightly wounded four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\nChief spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the military assessed that the drone was an upgraded Iranian-made Samad-3 model.\n\n\"Our estimation is that it arrived from Yemen to Tel Aviv,\" he told a briefing with journalists.\n\nHe also said there were \"increasing signs\" that Mohammed Deif, head of the military wing of Hamas, had been killed in an Israeli airstrike last week.\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv, which comes ahead of a visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu next week, is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nAn Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the drone was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" the military official told journalists after the strike.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures. The mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthi militants, which like Hezbollah are aligned with Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons.\"\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa\", which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars.\n\n\"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and four people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries. Four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, health services said.\n\nFootage from the site showed an apparent impact on a building located close to US embassy premises in Tel Aviv.\n\nIsraeli media said fragments from a drone of a kind widely used by Iranian-backed militia groups in the region had been recovered nearby.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians, after Israel invaded the Gaza Strip following last year's attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel.\n\nHamas-led fighters stormed Israeli towns on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and taking more than 250 hostages back to Gaza, according to Israeli tallies. Since then, more than 38,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's assault on the Gaza Strip, according to health authorities in the enclave.", "source": {"uri": "middle-east-online.com", {"uri": "8234028756", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "19:05:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T19:05:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T19:04:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2481103/houthis-claim-responsibility-for-attack-on-tel-aviv-with-iranian-made-drones", "title": "Houthis claim responsibility for attack on Tel Aviv with Iranian-made drones", "body": "An Iranian-made drone struck Tel Aviv, killing one and wounding four.\n\nIranian-made drone hit the centre of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday in an attack claimed by the Yemen-based Houthi militia that killed one man and wounded four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which footage shared on social media suggested came from the sea and did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\nChief spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the military assessed that the drone, which hit a building near the beachfront close to U.S. Embassy premises in Tel Aviv, was an upgraded Iranian-made Samad-3 model.\n\n\"Our estimation is that it arrived from Yemen to Tel Aviv,\" he told a press briefing.\n\nA spokesman for the Houthis, which like Hezbollah are aligned with Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nThe attack, which took place ahead of a visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu next week, is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nDefence Minister Yoav Gallant met military commanders to review air defences and said the country had to be ready for all scenarios. \"We must be prepared for defensive and offensive actions,\" he said, according to a statement from his office.\n\nAn Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the aircraft was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" the military official told journalists after the strike.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures.\n\nThe mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nIn the hours following Friday's attack, sirens sounded repeatedly in areas close to the border with Lebanon and Israeli air defences intercepted at least one aerial target that crossed into Israel.\n\nHouthi spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa\", which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars.\n\n\"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said in a televised speech.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and four people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries. Four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, health services said.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians, after Israel invaded the Gaza Strip following last year's attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel.\n\nHamas-led fighters stormed Israeli towns on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and taking more than 250 hostages back to Gaza, according to Israeli tallies. {"uri": "2024-07-426733568", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "06:02:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T06:02:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T05:57:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://en.tempo.co/read/1893359/tel-aviv-blast-was-apparent-drone-attack-military-says", "title": "Tel Aviv Blast Was Apparent Drone Attack, Military Says", "body": "TEMPO.CO, Tel Aviv - An apparent drone attack that was claimed by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia hit central Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday, July 19, killing one man and slightly wounding four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\n\"An initial inquiry indicates that the explosion in Tel Aviv was caused by the falling of an aerial target, and no sirens were activated. The incident is under thorough review,\" the military said in a statement.\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nIt said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defense measures, however, the mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic center, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthi militants, which like Hezbollah are backed by Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50-year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and said the circumstances were being investigated.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu faced heated opposition in the Knesset on Wednesday from opposition lawmakers.\n\nFour people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries and four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, the hospital said.\n\nFootage from the site showed an apparent impact on a building located close to U.S. embassy premises in Tel Aviv. Broken glass could be seen strewn across the city pavements as crowds of onlookers gathered nearby. The site was sealed off by police tape.\n\nIsraeli media said fragments from a drone of a kind widely used by Iranian-backed militia groups in the region had been recovered nearby.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians.\n\nIsrael invaded the Gaza Strip following an attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel in October last year.\n\nREUTERS", "source": {"uri": "en.tempo.co", "dataType": "news", "title": "TEMPO.CO"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8232972148", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "06:43:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T06:43:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T06:42:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/tel-aviv-hit-by-drone-attack-claimed-by-iranian-backed-houthis/articleshow/111854704.cms", "title": "Tel Aviv hit by drone attack claimed by Iranian-backed Houthis - Times of India", "body": "TEL AVIV: A large, long range drone hit the centre of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday in an attack claimed by the Iranian backed Houthi militia that killed one man and slightly wounded four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV (Unmanned aerial vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" an Israeli military official told journalists after the strike. The official did not confirm the claim from the Yemen based Houthi militia but said, \"We're not ruling out any possibilities right now.\"\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv is likely to fuel fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nThe Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the drone was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures. However, the mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthi militants, which, like Hezbollah, are backed by Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons.\"\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa,\" which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and was undetectable by radars. \"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and that the circumstances were being investigated.\n\nFour people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries and four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, the hospital said.\n\nFootage from the site showed an apparent impact on a building located close to US Embassy premises in Tel Aviv.\n\nIsraeli media said fragments from an drone of a kind widely used by Iranian backed militia groups in the region had been recovered nearby.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians.\n\nIsrael invaded the Gaza Strip following an attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel in October last {"uri": "8233419999", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:38:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:38:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:37:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/tel-aviv-hit-by-drone-attack-claimed-by-iranian-backed-houthis/articleshow/111863298.cms", "title": "Tel Aviv hit by drone attack claimed by Iranian-backed Houthis", "body": "A long-range Iranian-made drone struck central Tel Aviv early Friday, killing one and wounding four, in an attack claimed by Yemen's Houthi militia. The explosion occurred without triggering air raid alarms, hours after Israel killed a senior Hezbollah commander in Lebanon. The Israeli military identified the drone as an upgraded Iranian Samad-3, believed to have flown from Yemen. The attack, ahead of Prime Minister Netanyahu's US visit, raises fears of broader conflict as Houthis and other Iranian proxies align with Hamas amid the Gaza war.A long-range Iranian-made drone hit the centre of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday in an attack claimed by the Yemen-based Houthi militia that killed one man and wounded four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which footage shared on social media suggested came from the sea and did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\nChief spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the military assessed that the drone, which hit a building near the beachfront close to U.S. Embassy premises in Tel Aviv, was an upgraded Iranian-made Samad-3 model.\n\n\"Our estimation is that it arrived from Yemen to Tel Aviv,\" he told a press briefing.\n\nA spokesman for the Houthis, which like Hezbollah are aligned with Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nThe attack, which took place ahead of a visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu next week, is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nDefence Minister Yoav Gallant met military commanders to review air defences and said the country had to be ready for all scenarios. \"We must be prepared for defensive and offensive actions,\" he said, according to a statement from his office.\n\nAn Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the aircraft was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" the military official told journalists after the strike.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures. The mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nIn the hours following Friday's attack, sirens sounded repeatedly in areas close to the border with Lebanon and Israeli air defences intercepted at least one aerial target that crossed into Israel.\n\nOPERATION ACHIEVED ITS GOALS\n\nHouthi spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa\", which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars.\n\n\"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said in a televised speech.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and four people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries. Four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, health services said.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians, after Israel invaded the Gaza Strip following last year's attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel.\n\nHamas-led fighters stormed Israeli towns on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and taking more than 250 hostages back to Gaza, according to Israeli tallies. Since then, nearly 39,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's assault on the Gaza Strip, according to health authorities in the enclave.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13651517/Moment-Houthi-drone-flies-low-beach-embassy-exploding-Tel-Aviv-killing-one-person-injuring-ten-Israel-vows-settle-score.html", "title": "'Houthi' drone flies over US embassy before exploding in Tel Aviv", "body": "The drone had been detected but not shot down due to 'human error'\n\nThis is the moment a 'Houthi' drone flew over a beach and the US embassy in Israel before causing an explosion that killed one person with the country now vowing to 'settle the score'.\n\nFootage uploaded to social media shows the aerial weapon skimming over the Tel Aviv beach and a nearby row of buildings early this morning before an orange flash erupts further inland within seconds.\n\nThe terrifying video comes after an Israeli military official told a briefing that 'a very big drone that can travel long distances crashed into an apartment building' at 03.12am local time.\n\nThe official, who remained anonymous, said the aim was 'terrorism', with the rebel group's 'main goal to kill civilians in Israel'.\n\nThey added the drone had shockingly been detected by the military while airborne but the alarm was not immediately raised due to 'human error'.\n\nFootage captured the moment a 'Houthi' drone flew low over a beach and towards a row of buildings in Tel Aviv before causing an apartment building to explode\n\nAn orange glow is seen at the site of the explosion which left one dead and 10 more injured\n\nMembers of the Israeli security forces are seen at a cordoned-off area where the explosion took place near the US embassy in Tel Aviv on July 19, 2024\n\n'There was no alert that sounded in Tel Aviv because it wasn't activated,' he said\n\n'There was a human error that caused the interception and defence systems not to be operated,' the official said.\n\n'Obviously, one of the possibilities we're looking into is Yemen because of the Houthi announcements. But we're not ruling out anything.'\n\nRead More Hamas leader 'under pressure to agree ceasefire with Israel due to suffering in Gaza'\n\nIsrael's Defence Minister Yoav Gallant today issued a chilling warning, claiming: 'The defence establishment is working to immediately strengthen all defence systems, and will settle the score with anyone who harms the State of Israel or directs terror against it'.\n\nIDF Spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said that the UAV was apparently launched from Yemen.\n\n'We are still investigating the incident in depth. From evidence found at the scene, it would appear that the aircraft is an Iranian Samad-3 drone,' he said.\n\nYemen's Houthi group earlier today claimed responsibility for the attack that caused the explosion.\n\nA spokesperson for the Houthi armed forces said in a post on social media Friday that the Iran-aligned group had 'targeted Tel Aviv in occupied Palestine'.\n\nIt claimed that it had used a new drone 'capable of bypassing interceptor systems and being able to be detected by radars'.\n\nIt's armed wing also released a statement celebrating the attack, saying: 'Triumphing for the oppression of the Palestinian people and their mujahideen, and in retaliation to the Zionist enemy's massacres against the Palestinian people in the Gaza Strip'.\n\nThe Israeli military said it had now opened an investigation into the large, and fatal, explosion near the US embassy office and would work out why the country's air defence systems were not activated to intercept the 'aerial target' before any damage was caused.\n\nYemen's Iran-backed Houthi group claimed responsibility for the attack, saying it had 'targeted Tel Aviv in occupied Palestine'\n\nA Tel Aviv man stands next to a damaged car near the site of the deadly blast, amid the Israel-Hamas conflict in Tel Aviv\n\nFollowing the drone strike, Israel's air force took to social media claiming it had increased patrols to 'protect the country's skies'.\n\nIsraeli police said the body of a 50-year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion site, and that the circumstances surrounding his death were also being investigated.\n\nRead More Israel accuses Hamas of trying to 'hide' the results of its airstrike which killed 'at least 90'\n\nFour people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries and four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, the hospital said, according to France24.\n\nFootage and images from the devastating scene in Tel Aviv show mangled vehicles, smashed windows, and rubble strewn across the streets as authorities worked to detect casualties and assess the damage caused by the blast.\n\nIsraeli opposition politician, and leader of the centrist Yesh Atid party, Yair Lapid, said the attack was 'further proof that this government does not know and cannot give security to the citizens of Israel'.\n\n'Those who lose deterrence in the north and south also lose it in the heart of Tel Aviv,' he wrote on X.\n\n'There are no policies, no plans, all public relations and discussions about themselves. They [the government] have to go,' he continued.\n\nShards of glass can be seen smashed across the streets of Tel Aviv following the drone strike after the 'new' aerial weapon 'bypassed interceptor systems'\n\nEmergency personnel assist a woman at the site of the explosion in Tel Aviv\n\nRecalling the terrifying attack, local resident Alon told Haaretz: 'The whole building shook'.\n\n'My neighbours' windows shattered, so I was sure something had hit the building. It was only when I went outside that I realised that several buildings had been damaged.'\n\nThe incident came after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon on July 3.\n\nA Hezbollah statement at the time identified the killed commander as Mohammad Naameh Nasser, who went by the name Abu Naameh.\n\nA Hezbollah official speaking anonymously said he was head of the group's Aziz Unit, one of three regional divisions in southern Lebanon.\n\nBoth Hezbollah and the Houthis have stepped up their attacks against Israel, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians after Israel invaded the Gaza Strip during an initial attack by Hamas militants on a southern Israel music festival on October 7 last year.\n\nHamas militants killed around 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and took more than 200 others as hostages during the attack.\n\nThe war has so far killed more than 38,000 Palestinians, Gaza's health ministry {"uri": "8233024340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "07:21:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T07:21:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T07:20:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/tel-aviv-hit-by-drone-attack-claimed-by-iranian-backed-houthis/article_046b182f-5e26-597f-bb28-e2b603a79886.html", "title": "Tel Aviv hit by drone attack claimed by Iranian-backed Houthis", "body": "A building damaged at the site of an explosion is seen through the broken glass of a window, amid the Israel-Hamas conflict in Tel Aviv, Israel July 19, 2024. REUTERS/Ricardo Moraes\n\nBy Rami Amichay\n\nTEL AVIV (Reuters) - A large, long-range drone hit the centre of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday, in an attack claimed by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia that killed one man and slightly wounding four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" an Israeli military official told journalists after the strike. The official did not confirm the claim from the Yemen-based Houthi militia but said: \"We're not ruling out any possibilities right now.\"\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nThe Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the drone was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures, however the mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthi militants, which like Hezbollah are backed by Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa\", which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars. \"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and said the circumstances were being investigated.\n\nFour people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries and four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, the hospital said.\n\nFootage from the site showed an apparent impact on a building located close to U.S. embassy premises in Tel Aviv.\n\nIsraeli media said fragments from an drone of a kind widely used by Iranian-backed militia groups in the region had been recovered nearby.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians.\n\nIsrael invaded the Gaza Strip following an attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel in October last year.\n\n(Reporting by James Mackenzie; additional reporting by Ahmed Elimam and Clauda Tanios Editing by Christopher Cushing and Christian Schmollinger and Miral Fahmy)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE {"uri": "8233380541", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:12:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:12:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:11:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/houthis-claim-responsibility-for-long-range-drone-attacks-at-israel-s-tel-aviv-people-killed-injured-hamas-gaza-war-updates-2024-07-19-942653", "title": "Houthis claim responsibility for long-range drone attacks at Israel's Tel Aviv, one dead", "body": "Tel Aviv: Israeli military and emergency services said a long-range Iranian-made drone hit the centre of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday, killing one man and injuring four others. The attack, which occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed the killing of a senior commander of the Hezbollah group in southern Lebanon, was claimed by the Houthi rebels in Yemen.\n\nIsrael's military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the military assessed that the drone was an upgraded Iranian-made Samad-3 model. \"Our estimation is that it arrived from Yemen to Tel Aviv,\" he told a briefing with journalists. The attack on Tel Aviv is likely to fuel fears about further inflaming of tensions in the Middle East from the Gaza war, as Houthis and other Iran-backed proxies side with the Hamas militant group.\n\nAn Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger air alarms on Friday, but initial reports suggested the drone was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error. \"We're talking about a large UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" the military official told journalists after the strike.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthis, which like Hezbollah are aligned with Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war. Houthi spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nHe further said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa\", which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars. \"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said.\n\nThe Houthis have repeatedly launched drones and missiles toward Israel throughout the nine-month-long war, in solidarity with the Palestinian people and against Israel. But until Friday, all were intercepted by either Israel or Western allies with forces stationed in the region. Israel has so far not made attacks on the Houthis, allowing its allies instead to take the lead as it focuses its efforts on the war in Gaza and Hezbollah.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and four people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries. Four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, health services said.\n\nAn Israeli airstrike intended for Hamas military chief Mohammed Deif has killed at least 90 Palestinians in southern Gaza last week. Hagari said there were \"increasing signs\" that Mohammed Deif, head of the military wing of Hamas, had been killed in an Israeli airstrike last week.\n\nDeif is believed to be the chief mastermind behind the Hamas-led October 7 attack that killed 1,200 people in southern Israel and triggered the Israel-Hamas war. He has been on the top of Israel's most-wanted list for years and is believed to have escaped multiple Israeli assassination attempts in the past.\n\nHamas-led fighters stormed Israeli towns on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and taking more than 250 hostages back to Gaza, according to Israeli tallies. Since then, more than 38,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's assault on the Gaza Strip, according to health authorities in the enclave.\n\n(with inputs from agencies)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8233387524", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:16:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:16:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:15:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://cyprus-mail.com/2024/07/19/tel-aviv-hit-by-drone-attack-claimed-by-houthis/", "title": "Tel Aviv hit by drone attack claimed by Houthis", "body": "A long-range Iranian-made drone hit the centre of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday in an attack claimed by the Yemen-based Houthi militia that killed one man and wounded four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which footage shared on social media suggested came from the sea and did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\nChief spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the military assessed that the drone, which hit a building near the beachfront close to U.S. Embassy premises in Tel Aviv, was an upgraded Iranian-made Samad-3 model.\n\n\"Our estimation is that it arrived from Yemen to Tel Aviv,\" he told a press briefing.\n\nA spokesman for the Houthis, which like Hezbollah are aligned with Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nThe attack, which took place ahead of a visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu next week, is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nDefence Minister Yoav Gallant met military commanders to review air defences and said the country had to be ready for all scenarios. \"We must be prepared for defensive and offensive actions,\" he said, according to a statement from his office.\n\nAn Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the aircraft was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" the military official told journalists after the strike.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures. The mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nIn the hours following Friday's attack, sirens sounded repeatedly in areas close to the border with Lebanon and Israeli air defences intercepted at least one aerial target that crossed into Israel.\n\n\"OPERATION ACHIEVED ITS GOALS\"\n\nHouthi spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa\", which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars.\n\n\"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said in a televised speech.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and four people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries. Four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, health services said.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians, after Israel invaded the Gaza Strip following last year's attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel.\n\nHamas-led fighters stormed Israeli towns on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and taking more than 250 hostages back to Gaza, according to Israeli tallies. Since then, nearly 39,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's assault on the Gaza Strip, according to health authorities in the enclave.", "source": {"uri": "cyprus-mail.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8233496043", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "12:27:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T12:27:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:26:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/news/314473800/yemen-rebels-claim-deadly-hit-deep-inside-israel.html", "title": "Yemen rebels claim deadly hit deep inside Israel - Manila Standard", "body": "TEL AVIV - Yemen's Iran-backed Huthi rebels said they fired a drone that caused an explosion in Tel Aviv early Friday that left one person dead, injured four and set off a new shock for Israel more than nine months into its war in Gaza.\n\nThe Israeli military said an initial investigation showed the blast was caused by \"the falling of an aerial target\" that did not set off alarms. It said air patrols had been stepped up.\n\nAn Israeli military official said a \"very big\" drone was used in an attack on Tel Aviv on Friday that killed one person, and \"human error\" led to the missile not being intercepted.\n\nYemen's Huthi rebels claimed responsibility for the attack that caused an explosion at a building near the US embassy in Tel Aviv.\n\nThe military official told a briefing an attack by the Iran-backed Huthis was \"one of the possibilities\" being investigated.\n\nThe official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said \"a very big drone that can travel long distances\" was used in the attack which was at 3.12 am.\n\nHe said the drone \"crashed into an apartment building\" and \"it wasn't a tiny drone\".\n\nThe official said the aim was \"terrorism.\" \"Their main goal was to kill civilians in Israel.\"\n\nThe official said the drone was detected but the alarm was not immediately raised because of \"human error.\"\n\n\"There was no alert that sounded in Tel Aviv because it wasn't activated.\n\n\"There was a human error that caused the interception and defence systems not to be operated,\" the official said.\n\n\"Obviously, one of the possibilities we're looking into is Yemen because of the Huthi announcements. But we're not ruling out anything.\"\n\nThe official said another drone was detected on Israel's eastern border.\n\n\"Last night, there was another incident where we thwarted a UAV on our eastern border, another UAV.\" He gave no details on where it came from.\n\nThe Huthis, who have carried out dozens of attacks against Red Sea shipping to show support for Palestinians during the Gaza war, said their \"UAV force\" attacked \"one of the important targets in the occupied Jaffa region, what is now called Israeli Tel Aviv.\"\n\nThe rebels last Saturday had said they would \"not hesitate to expand its military operations... until the aggression stops.\"\n\nIf an attack is confirmed, it would be the first to cause casualties in Tel Aviv since a rocket strike launched from Gaza wounded one person on May 26. Hundreds of rockets were fired at Tel Aviv in the Oct. 7 attacks that set off the war, but most were intercepted.\n\nIsraeli police said they received hundreds of reports around 3:00 am of \"a strong explosion.\"\n\nThe blast hit a building in a street near an annex of the US embassy in Israel, according to an AFP journalist, who saw broken windows.\n\nDuring the search, a man in his fifties was \"found dead in his apartment\" bearing injuries caused by shrapnel, police said.\n\nIn Beirut, Israeli strikes on Thursday killed at least five people, including the commander of a Hamas-allied group in Lebanon, militant groups and a security source said.\n\nSince Hamas's Oct. 7 attack on Israel sparked war in Gaza, Israel has repeatedly targeted militants of Jamaa Islamiya, whose armed wing has launched attacks on Israel from southern Lebanon over the past nine months.\n\nA Lebanese security source said that an Israeli strike on a house near the southern village of Jmaijmeh killed three people and wounded several more.\n\nHezbollah said two of its members were among the dead, including Ali Jaafar Maatouq. A source close to the Islamist group described him as a commander of its elite Al Radwan operational unit.\n\nThe Israeli army confirmed that its air force had \"eliminated\" Ali Jaafar Maatouq in a strike against \"a command centre where Hezbollah terrorists were operating in the Jmaijmeh region.\"\n\nThe Magen David Adom emergency medical service said in a statement that it treated a man and a woman injured in their home, and two others hurt in the street. All four were taken to hospital with \"relatively minor\" injuries, it said.\n\n\"It may have been an aerial explosion... We were very lucky,\" said Peretz Amar, the Tel Aviv police commander, adding that \"the investigation is ongoing.\"\n\nA Tel Aviv resident told AFP that he was awakened by the explosion and \"everything shook\".\n\nPolice called on residents to \"respect safety instructions and not to approach or touch debris or shrapnel that may contain explosives.\"\n\nThe fire brigade said it was possible that a drone had caused the explosion.\n\nThe war in Gaza began with the Oct. 7 attack by Palestinian Hamas militants on Israel which resulted in the deaths of 1,195 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 42 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's military retaliation has killed at least 38,848 people, also mostly civilians, according to figures from the Gaza health ministry.", "source": {"uri": "manilastandard.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila The incident is under thorough review,\" the military said in a statement.\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nIt said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures, however the mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthi militants, which like Hezbollah are backed by Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and said the circumstances were being investigated.\n\nFour people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries and four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, the hospital said.\n\nFootage from the site showed an apparent impact on a building located close to U.S. embassy premises in Tel Aviv. Broken glass could be seen strewn across the city pavements as crowds of onlookers gathered nearby. The site was sealed off by police tape.\n\nIsraeli media said fragments from an drone of a kind widely used by Iranian-backed militia groups in the region had been recovered nearby.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians.\n\nIsrael invaded the Gaza Strip following an attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel in October last year. {"uri": "8233333824", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "10:43:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T10:43:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T10:43:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://kayhanlife.com/news/middle-east/tel-aviv-hit-by-drone-attack-claimed-by-islamic-republic-backed-houthis/", "title": "Tel Aviv Hit by Drone Attack Claimed by Islamic Republic-Backed Houthis - KAYHAN LIFE", "body": "Spanish, German Police Detain Four Suspected of Trafficking Drone Parts to Islamic-Republic Backed Hezbollah\n\nThe explosion, which did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\nChief spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the military assessed that the drone was an upgraded Iranian-made Samad-3 model.\n\n\"Our estimation is that it arrived from Yemen to Tel Aviv,\" he told a briefing with journalists.\n\nHe also said there were \"increasing signs\" that Mohammed Deif, head of the military wing of Hamas, had been killed in an Israeli airstrike last week.\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv, which comes ahead of a visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu next week, is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nAn Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the drone was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" the military official told journalists after the strike.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures. The mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthi militants, which like Hezbollah are aligned with Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa\", which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars.\n\n\"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said.\n\nIslamic Republic Made Sea-Launched Ballistic Missile Available to Houthis, Tasnim Newspaper Says\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and four people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries. Four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, health services said.\n\nFootage from the site showed an apparent impact on a building located close to U.S. embassy premises in Tel Aviv.\n\nIsraeli media said fragments from a drone of a kind widely used by Iranian-backed militia groups in the region had been recovered nearby.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians, after Israel invaded the Gaza Strip following last year's attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel.\n\nHamas-led fighters stormed Israeli towns on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and taking more than 250 hostages back to Gaza, according to Israeli tallies. {"uri": "8233106918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "08:17:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T08:17:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T08:17:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/israel-telaviv-bombing-drone-attack-houthi-rebels-b2582435.html", "title": "Man killed in drone strike on Tel Aviv claimed by Yemen's Houthis", "body": "A drone allegedly launched by Yemen's Houthi rebels hit near a US embassy office in Tel Aviv, killing one person and injuring eight.\n\nThe Israeli military said in a statement on Friday they believe a falling \"aerial target\" caused the explosion. The military has increased air patrols following the attack \"to protect Israeli airspace\".\n\nThe attack came just hours after Israeli airstrikes killed two commanders of the militant group Hezbollah in Lebanon. The Israeli military claimed the commanders had conducted multiple attacks against Israel.\n\nThe military and emergency services are reportedly investigating the attack on Tel Aviv, with the city on high alert.\n\nAccording to the Israeli military, its preliminary investigation indicates that the drone was detected by air defences but it was not intercepted due to human error.\n\nA 50-year-old man was killed in the attack. He was discovered with severe shrapnel wounds in an apartment next to the blast, according to Roee Klein, a paramedic with the national emergency service, the Washington Post reported.\n\nIsrael's air force believe the drone came from the southern direction, possibly Yemen, although it is not ruling out other launch sites, such as Iraq or Syria, the Times of Israel said.\n\nA military spokesman for the Houthis, who have been targeting the Israeli port city of Eilat with drones for months, announced on social media early on Friday that the group will disclose details of the \"quality operation\" targeting Tel Aviv.\n\nTel Aviv's mayor, Ron Huldai, wrote on X that the city was on \"heightened alert\" in light of the drone attack. He said: \"The war is still here, and it is hard and painful.\"\n\nFootage from the explosion site showed shattered glass scattered across the pavements, with crowds of onlookers congregating near a building marked by blast damage.\n\nThe area was cordoned off with police tape.\n\nIsraeli opposition politician Yair Lapid said the attack was \"further proof that this government does not know and cannot give security to the citizens of Israel\".\n\nHe added: \"Those who lose deterrence in the north and south also lose it in the heart of Tel Aviv. There are no policies, no plans, all public relations and discussions about themselves. They [the government] have to go.\"\n\nThe Houthis have consistently fired drones and missiles at Israel and Israeli-affiliated shipping in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden to demonstrate their support for Palestinians amid Israel's war on Hamas.\n\nAlmost 39,000 Palestinians have been killed since 7 October last year when Israel launched its war on Gaza. {"uri": "2024-07-426779746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "06:57:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T06:57:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T06:21:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israeli-military-says-tel-aviv-blast-apparently-caused-by-drone-2024-07-19/", "title": "Tel Aviv hit by drone attack claimed by Iranian-backed Houthis", "body": "TEL AVIV, July 19 (Reuters) - A large, long-range drone hit the centre of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday, in an attack claimed by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia that killed one man and slightly wounding four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) that can fly large distances,\" an Israeli military official told journalists after the strike. The official did not confirm the claim from the Yemen-based Houthi militia but said: \"We're not ruling out any possibilities right now.\"\n\nThe attack on Tel Aviv is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war, as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian militant group Hamas.\n\nThe Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the drone was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defence measures, however the mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic centre, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nA spokesman for Yemen's Houthi militants, which like Hezbollah are backed by Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nIn a televised speech, spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons\".\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa\", which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars. \"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and said the circumstances were being investigated.\n\nFour people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries and four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, the hospital said.\n\nFootage from the site showed an apparent impact on a building located close to U.S. embassy premises in Tel Aviv.\n\nIsraeli media said fragments from an drone of a kind widely used by Iranian-backed militia groups in the region had been recovered nearby.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians.\n\nIsrael invaded the Gaza Strip following an attack by Hamas militants on southern Israel in October last year.\n\nReporting by James Mackenzie; additional reporting by Ahmed Elimam and Clauda Tanios Editing by Christopher Cushing and Christian Schmollinger and Miral Fahmy\n\nOur Standards: The Thomson {"uri": "8233589390", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "13:29:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T13:29:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T13:28:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.algemeiner.com/2024/07/19/tel-aviv-hit-drone-attack-claimed-iranian-backed-houthis/", "title": "Tel Aviv Hit by Drone Attack Claimed by Iranian-Backed Houthis", "body": "A long-range Iranian-made drone hit the center of Tel Aviv in the early hours of Friday in an attack claimed by the Yemen-based Houthi militia, an internationally designated terrorist group, that killed one man and wounded four others, the Israeli military and emergency services said.\n\nThe explosion, which footage shared on social media suggested came from the sea and did not trigger air raid alarms, occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah terrorist group in southern Lebanon.\n\nChief spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the military assessed that the drone, which hit a building near the beachfront close to US Embassy premises in Tel Aviv, was an upgraded Iranian-made Samad-3 model.\n\n\"Our estimation is that it arrived from Yemen to Tel Aviv,\" he told a press briefing.\n\nA spokesman for the Houthis, which like Hezbollah are aligned with Iran, said the group had attacked Tel Aviv with a drone and would continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza war.\n\nThe attack, which took place ahead of a visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu next week, is likely to fan fears about further fallout from the Gaza war as the Houthis and other Iranian proxies side with the Palestinian terrorist group Hamas.\n\nDefense Minister Yoav Gallant met military commanders to review air defenses and said the country had to be ready for all scenarios. \"We must be prepared for defensive and offensive actions,\" he said, according to a statement from his office.\n\nAn Israeli official said the military was still investigating why the drone did not trigger the alarm, but initial reports suggested the aircraft was identified but the sirens were not sounded due to human error.\n\n\"We're talking about a large UAV [Unmanned Aerial Vehicle] that can fly large distances,\" the military official told journalists after the strike.\n\nThe military said air patrols had been increased to protect Israeli airspace but said it had not ordered new civil defense measures. The mayor of Tel Aviv said the city, Israel's economic center, had been moved to a state of heightened alert.\n\nIn the hours following Friday's attack, sirens sounded repeatedly in areas close to the border with Lebanon and Israeli air defenses intercepted at least one aerial target that crossed into Israel.\n\n\"OPERATION ACHIEVED ITS GOALS\"\n\nHouthi spokesperson Yahya Saree called Tel Aviv a primary target \"within the range of our weapons.\"\n\nHe said the strike was carried out using a new drone called \"Yafa,\" which he said was capable of bypassing interception systems and undetectable by radars.\n\n\"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said in a televised speech.\n\nIsrael's emergency services said the body of a 50 year-old man was found in an apartment close to the explosion and four people were taken to hospital with slight shrapnel injuries. Four others were treated for shock. All of them were later released, health services said.\n\nIsrael has been exchanging daily missile and artillery fire with Hezbollah along its northern border and in southern Lebanon since the start of the war in Gaza, prompting fears of a wider regional conflict if the situation escalates.\n\nThe Houthis have also stepped up attacks against Israel and Western targets, saying they are acting in solidarity with the Palestinians, after Israel invaded the Gaza Strip following last year's attack by Iran-backed Hamas terrorists on southern Israel.\n\nHamas-led fighters stormed Israeli towns on Oct. 7, killing around 1,200 people and taking more than 250 hostages back to Gaza. Israel responded with a military campaign in Hamas-ruled Gaza aimed at freeing the hostages and dismantling the terrorist group's military and governing capabilities.\n\nHamas-controlled health authorities in Gaza say 39,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's campaign, although experts have cast doubt on the reliability of such figures, in part because they don't distinguish between Israel and Hezbollah have been exchanging tit-for-tat strikes across the border for months, raising fears they are edging closer to all-out war.\n\nIsrael's Defense Forces said in a statement that an initial investigation indicated the explosion in Tel Aviv was caused by \"the falling of an aerial target\" - language typically used to refer to drones. The blast killed a 50-year-old man, according to Magen David Adom, Israel's emergency service. Several people sustained shrapnel wounds.\n\nA military spokesman for the Houthis claimed the group attacked Tel Aviv with a drone that was able to evade Israel's missile and drone warning and interception systems and will continue to target Israel in solidarity with Palestinians in the war in Gaza.
