In addition to confirming the finding of a corpse with shrapnel wounds, Israeli police also said that three other people were hurt in the explosion.\n\nTo control the situation, a sizable police contingent from the Tel Aviv neighborhood quickly arrived on the scene. In order to determine the source of the explosion, authorities have cordoned off the area and are aggressively looking for shrapnel bits.\n\nThe explosion was determined by the Israeli military to be the consequence of a drone detonation. The inability of air defenses and air raid sirens to intercept the drone has prompted an official inquiry. Sirens were not triggered because, as the Israeli Home Front Command had earlier declared, there was no observed violation of airspace.\n\nThe Houthi military spokesperson, Yahya Saree, said on Friday morning that the air force of the group carried out a \"special operation\" in Tel Aviv with the aid of a brand-new \"Yafa\" drone. man and a 25-year-old woman were reportedly hit by glass shrapnel - leaving them needing medical treatment.\n\nA man was found dead in an apartment near to the explosion with police investigating {"uri": "8233101907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "08:14:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T08:14:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T08:13:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.thedefensepost.com/2024/07/19/tel-aviv-drone-attack/", "title": "Yemen's Houthis Claim Responsibility for Tel Aviv Drone Attack", "body": "Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi rebels claimed responsibility for a drone attack Friday on the Israeli city of Tel Aviv that left one person dead.\n\nThe rebels fired a \"new drone called 'Yafa', which is capable of bypassing the enemy's interception systems,\" Houthi military spokesman Yahya Saree said in a statement on social media.\n\nThe Houthis have launched dozens of drone and missile strikes targeting shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden since November in a campaign they say is intended to signal solidarity with Palestinians during the Gaza war.\n\nThe latest attack struck \"one of the important targets in the occupied Jaffa region, what is now called Israeli Tel Aviv,\" the statement said, adding that \"the operation has achieved its goals successfully.\"\n\nThe Houthi announcement came after Israeli police on Friday reported a powerful explosion at a building in Tel Aviv around 3:00 am (0000 GMT).\n\nPolice said a search after the attack revealed one man \"dead in his apartment,\" bearing injuries caused by shrapnel.\n\nIsraeli emergency medical services said four people were taken to hospital with \"relatively minor\" injuries.\n\nThe Israeli army said the blast was \"caused by the falling of an aerial target,\" according to an initial inquiry.\n\nA military official later told reporters that a \"very big\" drone was responsible. It was detected but the alarm was not immediately raised because of \"human error,\" the official said.\n\n\"No sirens were activated,\" an army statement said, adding that the air force had \"increased its air patrols in order to protect Israeli airspace.\"\n\nThe Houthis' military spokesman said last Saturday that his group \"will not hesitate to expand its military operations... until the aggression stops.\"\n\nThe threat came after the health ministry in Hamas-run Gaza said at least 90 people were killed and 300 injured in a strike on Al-Mawasi camp for displaced people. Israel said the strike targeted Hamas military commanders behind the October 7 attack that sparked the Gaza war between Hamas and Israel.\n\nThe Houthis have previously alleged several attacks targeting the southern Israeli port city of Eilat on the Gulf of Aqaba, but Friday's strike is the first operation claimed by the rebels against Tel Aviv, deep inside Israel.\n\nThe rebels on Friday declared the Israeli commercial hub \"an unsafe area,\" saying it \"will be a primary target within the range of our weapons.\"\n\nSaree said the Houthis \"have a bank of targets\" in Israel, including \"sensitive military and security targets.\"\n\nThey \"will continue... to strike those targets in response to the enemy's massacres and daily crimes against our people in the Gaza Strip,\" Saree said.\n\nIn a separate incident on Friday, projectiles struck a container ship off the coast of Yemen without causing any injuries, an attack likely carried out by the Houthis, maritime security firm Ambrey said.\n\n\"A Singapore-flagged container ship was 'hit' by projectiles\" 80 nautical miles (148 kilometers) southeast of the Yemeni port city of Aden, Ambrey said in an advisory, adding that no injuries were reported in the attack that is consistent with previous Houthi operations.\n\nBritish maritime security agency UKMTO also said a \"vessel has been hit by unknown projectiles\" southeast of Aden.\n\n\"All crew reported safe. Authorities are investigating,\" said the United Kingdom Maritime Trade Operations, which is run by Britain's Royal Navy.\n\nHouthi attacks have prompted some shipping companies to detour around southern Africa to avoid the Red Sea, a vital route that normally carries about 12 percent of global trade, according to the International Chamber of Shipping.\n\nEgypt's Suez Canal on Thursday reported a 23.4-percent drop in revenues attributed to disruptions in Red Sea shipping over the past year.", "source": {"uri": "thedefensepost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Defense Post"}, {"uri": "8234023907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "18:59:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T18:59:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T18:59:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://punchng.com/israel-threatens-reprisals-for-deadly-yemen-rebel-drone-strike/", "title": "Israel threatens reprisals for deadly Yemen rebel drone strike", "body": "Israel threatened reprisals Friday after a drone claimed by Yemen's Huthi rebels penetrated its vaunted air defences and killed a civilian in a Tel\n\nAviv apartment building near a US embassy annexe.\n\nThe attack drew condemnation from UN chief Antonio Guterres and an appeal for \"maximum restraint\" to avoid \"further escalation in the region\".\n\nThe pre-dawn strike came hours before Israel suffered another blow, a ruling by the UN's top court that its occupation of the Palestinian territories was \"illegal\" and needed to end as soon as possible.\n\nThe advisory opinion of The Hague-based International Court of Justice is not binding, but it comes amid mounting international condemnation of Israel's handling of its war on Hamas in Gaza.\n\nThe office of Palestinian president Manmud Abbas hailed the court's decision as \"a victory for justice\".\n\nBut Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has overseen a major expansion of Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, insisted: \"The Jewish people are not occupiers in their own land.\"\n\nThe Huthis are one of a number of Iran-backed armed groups around the Middle East that have claimed drone and missile attacks on Israel in retaliation for the Gaza war.\n\nThey have previously claimed attacks on Israeli cities including Ashdod, Haifa and Eilat, but Friday's strike appears to be the first to breach Israel's sophisticated air defences.\n\nThe Huthis fired at Tel Aviv a \"new drone called 'Yafa', which is capable of bypassing the enemy's interception systems\", their spokesman Yahya Saree said.\n\nAn Israeli military official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a \"very big drone that can travel long distances\" was used in the 3:12 am (0012 GMT) attack.\n\nHe said the drone was detected but due to \"human error\" the alarm was not raised in time, and it slammed into an apartment building.\n\nMilitary spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said Israel believed the drone used was Iranian-made and upgraded so it could reach Tel Aviv from Yemen -- at least 1,800 kilometres (1,100 miles) away.\n\nIt was \"likely a Samad-3 model, which we estimate was launched from Yemen and reached Tel Aviv,\" he said, adding one civilian was killed and others lightly injured. Medical services said four people suffered \"relatively minor\" injuries.\n\nDefence Minister Yoav Gallant vowed to avenge the drone attack.\n\n\"The security system will settle the score with all who try to harm the state of Israel, or sends terrorism against it, in a decisive and surprising manner,\" he said in comments posted on social media platform X.\n\n* 'Everything blew out' -\n\nIn grainy security camera footage, the buzz of what appeared to be the drone was followed by an explosion that shook the building and set off car alarms.\n\nThe blast occurred about 100 metres (300 feet) from a US embassy annexe, said an AFP journalist who saw broken windows along the street lined with apartment blocks.\n\n\"It woke me up because the vibration of the sound was like a 747 (jet) coming in,\" said Kenneth Davis, an Israeli who was staying in a hotel opposite the building which was hit.\n\n\"And then the explosion... everything blew out in the room,\" he told AFPTV.\n\nHagari said Israel \"intercepted another UAV trying to infiltrate from the east\" at around the same time as the Tel Aviv attack.\n\n\"We are investigating why the UAV was not identified as a threat and intercepted before it struck,\" he said.\n\nIn recent weeks, the Islamic Resistance in Iraq, a loose alliance of Iran-backed groups, has claimed drone strikes against targets in Israel, labelling many of them \"joint operations\" with the Huthis.\n\nSince November, the Huthis have also carried out dozens of drone and missile attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden that they claim is Israeli-linked.\n\nThe United States and Britain launched a campaign of air strikes in January to deter the attacks on merchant vessels.\n\nThe Gaza war was triggered by Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel which resulted in the deaths of 1,195 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 42 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory campaign has killed at least 38,848 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory, where fighting raged on Friday.\n\n* WHO reports no polio cases -\n\nResidents said clashes were heard between Palestinian fighters and the Israeli army, with explosions and shelling in the Tal al-Hawa district of Gaza City.\n\nThe war has destroyed much of Gaza's housing and other infrastructure, leaving virtually the entire population displaced and short of food and drinking water.\n\nMany are living in unsanitary conditions. Health authorities in Gaza and Israel said on Thursday that poliovirus had been detected in Gaza sewage samples.", "source": {"uri": "punchng.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Punch Newspapers"}, {"uri": "8233398271", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:23:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:23:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:23:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/one-dead-as-huthi-claimed-drone-breaches-israel-defences/article_e88a38cc-a7dd-53ce-8634-354fa06003f4.html", "title": "One dead as Huthi-claimed drone breaches Israel defences", "body": "A Palestinian boy walks through heaps of garbage at a camp for displaced people in Khan Yunis, southern Gaza -- many are living in unsanitary conditions\n\nA drone claimed by Yemen's Huthi rebels slipped through Israel's vaunted air defence system on Friday to hit a Tel Aviv building near a US embassy annex, killing a civilian.\n\nThe Huthis fired at Tel Aviv a \"new drone called 'Yafa', which is capable of bypassing the enemy's interception systems,\" said Yahya Saree, the Iran-backed Yemeni movement's spokesman.\n\nThe Huthis have targeted shipping in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden with numerous drone and missile attacks since November, citing solidarity with Palestinians during the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza.\n\nThey have previously claimed attacks on Israeli cities including Ashdod, Haifa and Eilat, but Friday's strike appears to be the first to breach Israel's intricate air defences.\n\nIt comes after they threatened an escalation.\n\nAn Israeli military official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a \"very big drone that can travel long distances\" was used in the attack which killed one person and occurred at 3:12 am (0012 GMT).\n\nThe drone was detected, the official said, but due to \"human error\" the alarm was not raised in time, and it slammed into an apartment building.\n\nMilitary spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said Israel believed the drone the drone used was Iranian-made and upgraded so that it could reach Tel Aviv from Yemen -- at least 1,800 kilometres (1,100 miles) away.\n\nIt was \"likely a Samad-3 model, which we estimate was launched from Yemen and reached Tel Aviv,\" he said, adding the impact killed one civilian and lightly injured others.\n\nEmergency medical services said four people were taken to hospital with \"relatively minor\" injuries.\n\n- 'Everything blew out' -\n\nIn grainy security camera footage, the buzz of what appeared to be the drone was followed by an explosion that shook the building and set off car alarms.\n\nThe blast occurred about 100 metres (yards) from a US embassy annex, said an AFP journalist who saw broken windows along the street lined with apartment blocks.\n\n\"It woke me up because the vibration of the sound was like a 747 coming in,\" said Kenneth Davis, an Israeli who was staying in a hotel opposite the struck building.\n\n\"And then the explosion... everything blew out in the room, the windows and things from the ceiling, and it was on me, nothing heavy, but lots of pieces of stuff,\" he told AFPTV.\n\nHagari said Israel \"intercepted another UAV trying to infiltrate from the east\" at around the same time as the Tel Aviv attack.\n\n\"We are investigating why the UAV was not identified as a threat and intercepted before it struck,\" he said. \"I want to emphasise that (Israel's air) defence is not impenetrable.\"\n\nIn recent weeks, the Islamic Resistance in Iraq, a loose alliance of Iran-backed groups, has claimed drone strikes against targets in Israel, labelling many of them \"joint operations\" with the Huthis.\n\nThe Gaza war began with the October 7 attack by Palestinian Hamas militants on Israel which resulted in the deaths of 1,195 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 42 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's military retaliation has killed at least 38,848 people, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in Hamas-ruled Gaza, where fighting raged on Friday.\n\n- 'Moral stain' -\n\nResidents said clashes were heard between Palestinian fighters and the Israeli army, with explosions and shelling in the Tal al-Hawa district of Gaza City.\n\nThe war has destroyed much of Gaza's housing and other infrastructure, leaving almost all the population displaced, short of food and drinking water.\n\nMany are living in unsanitary conditions. Health authorities in Gaza and Israel said on Thursday that highly infectious polio has been detected in Gaza sewage samples.\n\n\"The humanitarian situation... is a moral stain on us all,\" said UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has repeatedly insisted that, despite mounting pressure both at home and from abroad, there would be no let-up in Israel's campaign against Hamas.\n\nFar-right members of his governing coalition oppose a truce deal, including National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir who on Thursday said Netanyahu must not make a \"surrender\" accord with Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu is set to address the US Congress next Wednesday.\n\nThe White House said President Joe Biden was expected to meet with him, but it will depend on the US leader's recovery from Covid.\n\nAhead of Netanyahu's visit, Israeli lawmakers passed a symbolic resolution opposing the creation of a Palestinian state -- a move criticised by the United Nations and one that clashes with US ambitions for the region.\n\nDespite the Israeli vote, White House National Security Council spokesman John Kirby reiterated \"our firm belief in the power and the promise of the two-state solution.\"\n\nburs-dv/it", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestinians", The Israeli military has confirmed the attack and said it claimed the life of one citizen.\n\nIn a televised statement earlier on 19 July, Houthi spokesperson Yahya Saree said the group's forces \"carried out a specific military operation\" that targeted \"the occupied Jafa region, what is now called Israeli Tel Aviv\".\n\nA new drone called 'Yafa' was used, he said, which is capable of bypassing interception systems and is undetectable by radars. \"The operation has achieved its goals successfully,\" Saree said.\n\nIsrael's military confirmed a building in Tel Aviv was hit by an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), causing one death and eight injuries.\n\n\"During the night, a UAV entered from the sea -- from the west -- which in our initial assessment was launched from Yemen,\" said Israeli Defence Force (IDF) spokesman brigadier general Daniel Hagari. He said IDF warning systems were not activated and the force is investigating the incident.\n\n\"According to the preliminary investigation and field indicators, it is clear that the drone was a 'Sammad 3' type, which departed from Yemen to Tel Aviv as per our estimates,\" he said. \"Sammad 3 is an Iranian combat vehicle that has been modernised for long range attacks.\"\n\nVideo footage posted on social media appear to show what could have been the impact of a drone a few hundred meters from the US embassy branch office in Tel Aviv.\n\nThis marks a significant escalation that might risk a regional spillover of the 10-month conflict between Israel and Palestinian group Hamas, especially with Israel highlighting the Iranian origin of the UAV. Israel and Iran avoided a full-blown war in April after a significant escalation led to exchanging direct aerial strikes against each other's territory.\n\nThe Houthis began attacking commercial ships in and around the Red Sea six weeks after the Israel-Hamas war broke out last year in what they claim is an act of solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.\n\nThe Houthis have stepped up their attacks on shipping in the past six weeks. It has repeatedly threatened to target Israel and its ports, but previous attempts have largely been intercepted or failed to reach the country. The IDF's Hageri Israel has been dealing with drones from Yemen since the beginning of the Gaza war.\n\n\"Dozens of UAVs have been launched from Yemen alone, most of which were intercepted or shot down while en route or before penetrating Israeli territory, most were intercepted by an US task force under Centcom command, and the rest were intercepted by planes or air force defense systems,\" he said.\n\nHouthi attacks have had a significant impact on crude and refined product shipments through the Suez Canal as many ships travelling between Europe and Asia have opted to avoid the Red Sea and take the longer route around the southern tip of Africa. {"uri": "8233766798", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "15:29:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T15:29:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T15:29:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/houthis-struck-deep-israel-iranian-143347941.html", "title": "The Houthis struck deep into Israel with an Iranian-made attack drone likely upgraded for longer-range strikes, IDF says", "body": "The rare strike marked the Iran-backed rebels' first lethal attack inside Israel.\n\nThe Houthi-launched drone that struck a building in Israel on Friday, killing one person and injuring several more, appears to have been modified for extended-range strikes, the Israeli military said.\n\nThe Houthis claimed responsibility for the rare attack on Tel Aviv early Friday morning local time, which marked their first lethal attack in Israel. The Iran-backed rebels said that they carried out a \"specific military operation\" with a new attack drone that is undetectable by radars and can effectively sneak past air-defense systems.\n\nRear Adm. Daniel Hagari, an IDF spokesperson, said an initial assessment suggests the system used in the attack was an Iranian-made Samad-3 one-way attack drone with an extended range. He said the drone was launched from Yemen and crossed into Israeli territory from the direction of the Mediterranean Sea.\n\nIn video footage from Friday's attack, the unmanned aircraft can be seen crossing over a beach in Tel Aviv and striking a building, causing a large explosion. The attack occurred near the US Embassy branch office, although it's unclear if that was the intended target. The resulting blast shattered windows and sent shrapnel falling into the streets.\n\nAccording to a February 2024 report by the US Defense Intelligence Agency, the Samad family of drones has a maximum range of just over 1,200 miles, which technically allows them to reach the bottom half of Israel.\n\nThe Houthis have launched dozens of drones from Yemen, although a majority have been intercepted before they could reach Israeli territory, Hagari said. He added that the IDF is investigating this latest incident to determine why the Samad-3 was not identified as a threat and shot down before it reached Tel Aviv.\n\n\"Today and in the coming days, we will conduct a situational assessment in order to examine the incident, understand exactly where the threat was launched from, what the necessary defensive responses are, and what the necessary operational responses are against those who threaten the State of Israel,\" Hagari said.\n\nLooking at the available information, Fabian Hinz, a research fellow for defense and military analysis at the International Institute for Strategic Studies think tank, said that \"it's possible\" that the drone used in the Tel Aviv attack is a \"slightly more capable\" Samad variant.\n\nHe wrote in commentary on social media that \"for the Houthis, increasing the UAV range would be quite attractive as it would allow them to strike targets further away, fly routes evading enemy defenses and attack from unexpected angles.\"\n\nThe Houthi said their drone strike was carried out in support of Palestinians in Gaza, the same rationale for their ongoing attacks on merchant shipping lanes in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden. The rebels have spent months launching one-way attack drones and anti-ship missiles into the waterways, often forcing US Navy and allied warships to intercept the threats.\n\nIsrael has yet to strike the Houthis directly in Yemen. The US and UK militaries, however, have carried out several rounds of joint strikes targeting rebel facilities there, and American forces have carried out a number of unilateral strikes.\n\nBeyond the Houthis, Iran also provides military and financial support to Hezbollah militants in Lebanon and Hamas in Gaza.\n\nFriday's attack took place hours after Israel killed a senior Hezbollah commander in southern Lebanon and raises long-standing fears that the devastating Gaza war could escalate further into a broader regional conflict.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": warns Houthi rebels, Iran of consequences over drone attack", "body": "'We will hold everyone who harms Israel accountable,' says Yoav Gallant\n\nThe Israeli defense minister on Friday warned the Yemeni Houthi group and Iran of consequences following a bomb-laden drone attack on Tel Aviv at dawn, which resulted in one fatality and 10 injuries.\n\n\"The security establishment is working to immediately reinforce all defense systems and will hold accountable anyone who harms the State of Israel or directs terrorism against it,\" said Yoav Gallant in a statement following an assessment with senior Israeli military officials concerning the drone attack on Tel Aviv.\n\nThe Israeli Public Broadcasting Corporation reported that his remarks were directed at Iran and the Houthis.\n\nEarly Friday morning, the Houthi group launched a surprise attack, marking the first instance of a bomb-laden drone targeting Tel Aviv.\n\nThrough its military spokesman Yahya Saree, the Yemeni Houthi group declared Tel Aviv an \"unsafe area\" and a \"primary target for its weapons.\"\n\nAt least one Israeli was killed and 10 others were injured in the drone attack.\n\nIsraeli army spokesman Daniel Hagari said the drone that hit Tel Aviv was an Iranian-made Samad-3 model and it is believed to have been launched from Yemen.\n\nThere has been no immediate response from the Iranian side concerning {"uri": "8233944518", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:47:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:47:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:46:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.afr.com/world/middle-east/yemen-s-houthis-take-credit-for-shock-drone-strike-in-tel-aviv-20240720-p5jv4t", "title": "Yemen's Houthis take credit for shock drone strike in Tel Aviv", "body": "The spokesman, Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, dismissed Houthi claims that the drone was a type of stealth aircraft and maintained it had been picked up by Israeli monitoring systems. A second drone targeting Israeli airspace was successfully intercepted early Friday, he said. Investigators were exploring whether the two attacks were related.\n\nThe drone that reached Tel Aviv was an Iranian-made Samad-3 that had been modified to fly greater distances, he said.\n\nThe Houthis, a Yemen-based group that has been attacking commercial ships in the Red Sea since last year, said Friday in a statement that it had carried out a \"military operation\" targeting Tel Aviv that \"successfully achieved its objectives\", using what it said was a new drone capable of evading countermeasures. The attack, the statement said, was in response to Israeli \"massacres\" in Gaza.\n\nWitnesses said they heard and saw an aircraft appear from the direction of the Mediterranean Sea around 3am and slam into a building with a loud explosion. There were no warning alarms in a city where residents are used to air raid sirens and alerts on their phones sending them to shelters.\n\nLimor Sagiv, 58, was asleep with her partner in a fifth-floor apartment less than two blocks from the US Embassy facility when the blast shattered their kitchen window and a balcony door.\n\n\"There was an orange flash and a smell like a rubber fire,\" said Sagiv, standing in a living room filled with glass shards. They had just returned to the apartment after being told by police to evacuate the area for a few hours in case of secondary attacks.\n\nNoa Yehoshua was up late with friends in a nearby apartment when one of them spotted a small aircraft with a round fuselage and wide wings.\n\n\"My friend was sitting by the window and said, 'Oh, wow, guys, what it that?'\" Yehoshua said. \"And then it just exploded.\"\n\nYehoshua, 23, an army reservist scheduled to deploy to Gaza next week, said the drone strike was part of the wider war with Iran-backed forces throughout the region that has raged since the Hamas raid on Israeli towns on October 7.\n\n\"It's so surreal that we're attacked over and over and over again in a war that we didn't even start,\" she said.\n\nDuring the war in Gaza, the Houthis and other Iran-backed groups in the region have carried out regular attacks they say are aimed at supporting Palestinian militant groups and ending Israel's military offensive. The Yemeni group has previously claimed drone attacks on the southern Israeli city of Eilat - roughly 1000 miles (1600 kilometres) from northern Yemen - but the strike on Tel Aviv, if confirmed, appears to represent an increase in the Houthis' capabilities and reach.\n\nThe Yemeni group said it would continue to target Tel Aviv with future attacks.\n\n\"The security system is working to immediately strengthen all defence systems, and will come to account with anyone who harms the State of Israel or sends terror against it,\" Defence Minister Yoav Gallant said in a statement on Friday.\n\nThe fatality was a 50-year-old man who was found with severe shrapnel injuries in an apartment adjacent to the blast, said Roee Klein, a paramedic with Magen David Adom, Israel's national emergency service. The nearby Ichilov Medical Centre said Friday it had treated and released five people injured in the strike.\n\nIsraeli media identified the fatality as Yevgeny Ferder, a Belarusian immigrant who arrived in Israel two years ago at the beginning of Russia's war in Ukraine. He was killed in the hotel where he both lived and worked, according to the reports.\n\nFriday's rare attack on Tel Aviv took place hours after the Israeli air force said it killed two commanders of Hezbollah, the Iran-backed group in Lebanon with which Israel has been exchanging fire. Hezbollah acknowledged the deaths of two of its members but did not identify them as senior operatives.\n\nIsrael's aerial defence system, outfitted primarily for rockets, has for months struggled to identify and eliminate Hezbollah drones - which fly lower and often in nonlinear paths - in attacks on Israel's north.\n\nFabian Hinz, a research fellow who studies drones and missiles at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, said that pictures of the debris from the drone that circulated Friday matched the Houthi Samad-3 drone, the group's \"standard long-range strike drone\".\n\nThe model had previously been used in strikes against Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates as well as the southern Israeli city of Eilat several times, in attacks that were intercepted, he said.\n\nWhile Houthi claims that the drone used on Friday could evade radar were \"certainly false\", it was also possible the group had upgraded the drone to increase its range, including by making the warhead lighter or increasing the size of the fuel tank. It was hard to pinpoint the exact range of the Samad-3, but Hinz said that estimates were between 1100 to 1500 miles.\n\nThe pictures of the debris appeared to show a \"slightly higher performance\" Iranian-made engine than those normally seen on the Samad-3, he said. It was unclear, he added, \"whether it's a standard Samad-3 version that just got lucky and got through, or whether it's a slightly upgraded or improved version\".\n\nWhile shorter-range versions of the Samad drones were piloted via a radio link and cameras, the longer-range models relied on satellite navigation. Such systems can be jammed, but antennas resistant to jamming had been observed on Iranian drones, he said.\n\nIt was difficult to determine exactly where the drone was launched from, given that it appeared to have changed direction at least once, as it headed to Tel Aviv from the Mediterranean Sea, Hinz said.\n\nOther Iranian-backed groups, in Iraq and Lebanon, had tended to use smaller Samad models than the one used Friday. If the Houthis had developed a longer-range drone, such a weapon would provide them with \"new angles of attack\" that could put additional strains on detection systems and Israel's capabilities.\n\nIf Yemen is determined to be the launch site, Israel would find it difficult to launch a counterstrike, according to Harrison Mann, a former US Army officer who worked at the Defence Intelligence Agency. Even the United States has struggled to locate Houthi targets, he said, and has already hit the most worthwhile one.\n\nHamas praised the drone attack in statement, and called on Yemeni militants to launch more of them in defence of the \"innocents in Gaza\".\n\nTel Aviv's mayor, Ron Huldai, posted on X that the city was on \"high alert\" after the drone attack and that residents were required to follow emergency instructions. \"The war is still here, and it is hard and painful,\" he said.\n\nIt was not immediately clear whether the drone was targeting the US Embassy branch office. US Embassy officials in Israel did not respond to request for comment early Friday.", "source": {"uri": "afr.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Financial Review"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8233987456", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "18:26:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T18:26:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T18:25:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/israel-threatens-reprisals-for-deadly-yemen-rebel-drone-strike/article_e88a38cc-a7dd-53ce-8634-354fa06003f4.html", "title": "Israel threatens reprisals for deadly Yemen rebel drone strike", "body": "Yemeni students chant anti-Israeli and anti-US slogans at a protest against the Gaza war in the rebel-held capital Sanaa on Wednesday\n\nIsrael threatened reprisals Friday after a drone claimed by Yemen's Huthi rebels penetrated its vaunted air defences and killed a civilian in a Tel Aviv apartment building near a US embassy annexe.\n\nThe attack drew condemnation from UN chief Antonio Guterres and an appeal for \"maximum restraint\" to avoid \"further escalation in the region\".\n\nThe pre-dawn strike came hours before Israel suffered another blow, a ruling by the UN's top court that its occupation of the Palestinian territories was \"illegal\" and needed to end as soon as possible.\n\nThe advisory opinion of The Hague-based International Court of Justice is not binding, but it comes amid mounting international condemnation of Israel's handling of its war on Hamas in Gaza.\n\nThe office of Palestinian president Manmud Abbas hailed the court's decision as \"a victory for justice\".\n\nBut Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has overseen a major expansion of Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, insisted: \"The Jewish people are not occupiers in their own land.\"\n\nThe Huthis are one of a number of Iran-backed armed groups around the Middle East that have claimed drone and missile attacks on Israel in retaliation for the Gaza war.\n\nThey have previously claimed attacks on Israeli cities including Ashdod, Haifa and Eilat, but Friday's strike appears to be the first to breach Israel's sophisticated air defences.\n\nThe Huthis fired at Tel Aviv a \"new drone called 'Yafa', which is capable of bypassing the enemy's interception systems\", their spokesman Yahya Saree said.\n\nAn Israeli military official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a \"very big drone that can travel long distances\" was used in the 3:12 am (0012 GMT) attack.\n\nHe said the drone was detected but due to \"human error\" the alarm was not raised in time, and it slammed into an apartment building.\n\nMilitary spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said Israel believed the drone used was Iranian-made and upgraded so it could reach Tel Aviv from Yemen -- at least 1,800 kilometres (1,100 miles) away.\n\nIt was \"likely a Samad-3 model, which we estimate was launched from Yemen and reached Tel Aviv,\" he said, adding one civilian was killed and others lightly injured. Medical services said four people suffered \"relatively minor\" injuries.\n\nDefence Minister Yoav Gallant vowed to avenge the drone attack.\n\n\"The security system will settle the score with all who try to harm the state of Israel, or sends terrorism against it, in a decisive and surprising manner,\" he said in comments posted on social media platform X.\n\n- 'Everything blew out' -\n\nIn grainy security camera footage, the buzz of what appeared to be the drone was followed by an explosion that shook the building and set off car alarms.\n\nThe blast occurred about 100 metres (300 feet) from a US embassy annexe, said an AFP journalist who saw broken windows along the street lined with apartment blocks.\n\n\"It woke me up because the vibration of the sound was like a 747 (jet) coming in,\" said Kenneth Davis, an Israeli who was staying in a hotel opposite the building which was hit.\n\n\"And then the explosion... everything blew out in the room,\" he told AFPTV.\n\nHagari said Israel \"intercepted another UAV trying to infiltrate from the east\" at around the same time as the Tel Aviv attack.\n\n\"We are investigating why the UAV was not identified as a threat and intercepted before it struck,\" he said.\n\nIn recent weeks, the Islamic Resistance in Iraq, a loose alliance of Iran-backed groups, has claimed drone strikes against targets in Israel, labelling many of them \"joint operations\" with the Huthis.\n\nSince November, the Huthis have also carried out dozens of drone and missile attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden that they claim is Israeli-linked.\n\nThe United States and Britain launched a campaign of air strikes in January to deter the attacks on merchant vessels.\n\nThe Gaza war was triggered by Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel which resulted in the deaths of 1,195 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 42 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory campaign has killed at least 38,848 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory, where fighting raged on Friday.\n\n- WHO reports no polio cases -\n\nResidents said clashes were heard between Palestinian fighters and the Israeli army, with explosions and shelling in the Tal al-Hawa district of Gaza City.\n\nThe war has destroyed much of Gaza's housing and other infrastructure, leaving virtually the entire population displaced and short of food and drinking water.\n\nMany are living in unsanitary conditions. Health authorities in Gaza and Israel said on Thursday that poliovirus had been detected in Gaza sewage samples.\n\nThe World Health Organization said on Friday that no cases of the highly infectious disease had been discovered in Gaza so far.\n\nburs-dv/jkb/kir", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sharon_aronowicz@ktbs.com", "name": "Sharon The Israeli authorities have not commented on responsibility for the explosion.\n\nThe Israeli military said in a statement that a preliminary investigation indicated that a falling aerial target caused the blast, and that no sirens had been activated. Tel Aviv's mayor, Ron Huldai, said the episode had involved a drone and that the city was on heightened alert.\n\n\"The war is still here, and it is hard and painful,\" he said on social media, referring to Israel's war with Hamas in the Gaza Strip.\n\nA spokesman for the Houthi militia, Yahya Sarea, said in a televised statement that the group had targeted Tel Aviv and that it would continue to target the city. The group used a new drone that can get past Israel's defense systems and is not detected by radar, he added.\n\nSince November, the Houthis, who are based in Yemen, have been attacking ships in a vital route in the Red Sea in a campaign in support of Palestinians.\n\nThe body of a 50-year-old man was found in a nearby apartment building as emergency workers were combing through the area around the explosion, according to a statement from Zaki Heller, a spokesman for Israel's national emergency service. The man was found in his apartment and had shrapnel injuries, the Tel Aviv police said in a statement.\n\nThe police said 10 people had been wounded and described them as \"lightly injured.\" Four of them suffered penetrating and blunt force trauma, said Roee Klein, a paramedic for the national emergency service, in a video.\n\nWitnesses described a \"very loud explosion\" that could be heard miles away. Surveillance video widely circulated on social media and verified by Storyful shows a bright flash of light, followed by a boom and the sound of an alarm.\n\nThe police said that a large number of forces was responding to the explosion. Except for the drone that hit tonight, all the launches were intercepted.\n\nLarge explosion rocks Tel Aviv\n\nA large explosion was heard early Friday morning on Ben Yehuda Street in Tel Aviv as a result of a drone attack, killing one person and injuring about ten. The deceased was found near the scene of the crash. He was sleeping in a room on the roof of a building when he was hit by shrapnel.\n\nPolice officers, ZAKA volunteers, and Tel Aviv Municipality employees arrived and treated the wounded.\n\nThe Tel Aviv Mayor, Ron Huldai, tweeted this morning: \"The Tel Aviv-Jaffa Municipality is moving to an increased state of alert in light of the severe drone incident tonight, in which one person was killed and others were injured.\"\n\n\"The war is still ongoing, and it is hard and painful. The municipal forces arrived at the spot quickly and dealt with the incident, and we are prepared for any developments. I call on the public to obey the instructions.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the US military intercepted several drones on the ground before they were launched. The launch options are from Syria, Iraq, and Yemen. In terms of past capabilities, it is possible that the launch was also carried out from Lebanon, but Hezbollah and Medina have not yet fired in the direction of the center.\n\nAccording to the {"uri": "2024-07-427267542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:30:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:30:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T13:20:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/israeli-city-of-tel-aviv-suffers-deadly-drone-strike-claimed-by-yemen-s-houthis/article_a0d12ee7-9b85-5ecf-856e-57b6a5623e82.html", "title": "Israeli city of Tel Aviv suffers deadly drone strike claimed by Yemen's Houthis", "body": "Galit Altstein, Mohammed Hatem and Marissa Newman - Bloomberg News (TNS)\n\nA drone strike killed a man in the heart of Tel Aviv on Friday morning, in an attack claimed by the Yemen-based Houthi militants.\n\nThe Iran-backed group said it attacked Israel's commercial capital with a new type of drone difficult for radar to detect and vowed to target the city and other parts of the country again.\n\nIsrael's military said the projectile was probably fired from Yemen and was an Iran-built Samad 3 drone re-purposed to fly longer distances.\n\nIf confirmed, it would mark the first deadly attack on Israel by the Houthis, who have also been assaulting ships much closer to home in recent months.\n\nThe incident comes just ahead of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's trip to Washington, his first outside of Israel since its war against Hamas began in October. He's due to meet U.S. President Joe Biden and address Congress on July 24.\n\nThe explosion happened close to Tel Aviv's sea front and a U.S. embassy branch, according to Israeli emergency services. The Israeli military said no sirens were activated and declined to comment if the American facility was the intended target.\n\nThe man who was killed was around 50 and eight people were injured. The attack happened close to 3 a.m. local time.\n\n\"An initial inquiry indicates that the explosion in Tel Aviv was caused by the falling of an aerial target,\" the Israeli military said.\n\nIt later added that the drone was detected and it's investigating why it wasn't shot down.\n\nThe Houthis started targeting Israel with drones and missiles shortly after the war in Gaza started. But, at least until now, none of their attacks are thought to have caused significant damage in Israel, with most being intercepted or failing to reach the country, which lies around 1,900 kilometers (1,180 miles) from Yemen.\n\nIsrael's largely avoided direct retaliation against the Houthis.\n\nDrone warfare has exposed a vulnerability in Israel's vaunted air defenses. The Iron Dome system -- which uses interceptors against incoming short-range missiles -- is effective against large objects, but many smaller drones are able to slip through.\n\nDozens of drones, primarily those fired by Hezbollah from Lebanon, have evaded the military's defenses this year and caused casualties and damage in Israel. The army is testing a laser-based system designed for small projectiles, though it won't be ready before 2025.\n\nThe Houthis have caused havoc in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden since November, attacking commercial and military ships and forcing most Western-linked vessels to avoid the area. They've stepped up those naval assaults in the past six weeks.\n\nThe Islamists say they're acting in solidarity with Palestinians and will continue their attacks until there's a cease-fire in Gaza.\n\nThey are, along with Hamas and Hezbollah in Lebanon, part of Iran's \"axis of resistance\" -- anti-U.S. and anti-Israel militias in the Middle East that receive training and funding from Tehran.\n\nSince Oct. 7, when Hamas attacked Israel from Gaza, several of those groups have targeted Israel, U.S. bases in region or Western commercial interests.\n\nThe likes of the U.S., European Union and India have moved warships to the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden in an attempt to thwart the Houthi shipping attacks. The U.S. and U.K. have also been striking Houthi positions in Yemen regularly since January. They say those have degraded the group's military capabilities, though it's still able to hit vessels and Iran continues to resupply it.\n\nBezalel Smotrich, Israel's far-right finance minister, said the drone strike on Tel Aviv showed that the government has to continue the war in Gaza until Hamas is destroyed.\n\n\"In a region where only strength and power are understood, we do not have the privilege of ending the war without a complete victory in all arenas and the removal of the threat posed by them,\" he said on X.\n\n-------\n\n(With assistance from Patrick Sykes and Paul Abelsky.)\n\n\u00a92024 Bloomberg L.P. {"uri": "8233395060", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:21:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:21:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:21:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/one-dead-as-huthi-claimed-drone-breaches-israel-defences/article_7a91aa94-2889-52a2-840a-c75e99d08675.html", "title": "One dead as Huthi-claimed drone breaches Israel defences", "body": "A Palestinian boy walks through heaps of garbage at a camp for displaced people in Khan Yunis, southern Gaza -- many are living in unsanitary conditions\n\nA drone claimed by Yemen's Huthi rebels slipped through Israel's vaunted air defence system on Friday to hit a Tel Aviv building near a US embassy annex, killing a civilian.\n\nThe Huthis fired at Tel Aviv a \"new drone called 'Yafa', which is capable of bypassing the enemy's interception systems,\" said Yahya Saree, the Iran-backed Yemeni movement's spokesman.\n\nThe Huthis have targeted shipping in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden with numerous drone and missile attacks since November, citing solidarity with Palestinians during the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza.\n\nThey have previously claimed attacks on Israeli cities including Ashdod, Haifa and Eilat, but Friday's strike appears to be the first to breach Israel's intricate air defences.\n\nIt comes after they threatened an escalation.\n\nAn Israeli military official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a \"very big drone that can travel long distances\" was used in the attack which killed one person and occurred at 3:12 am (0012 GMT).\n\nThe drone was detected, the official said, but due to \"human error\" the alarm was not raised in time, and it slammed into an apartment building.\n\nMilitary spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said Israel believed the drone the drone used was Iranian-made and upgraded so that it could reach Tel Aviv from Yemen -- at least 1,800 kilometres (1,100 miles) away.\n\nIt was \"likely a Samad-3 model, which we estimate was launched from Yemen and reached Tel Aviv,\" he said, adding the impact killed one civilian and lightly injured others.\n\nEmergency medical services said four people were taken to hospital with \"relatively minor\" injuries.\n\n- 'Everything blew out' -\n\nIn grainy security camera footage, the buzz of what appeared to be the drone was followed by an explosion that shook the building and set off car alarms.\n\nThe blast occurred about 100 metres (yards) from a US embassy annex, said an AFP journalist who saw broken windows along the street lined with apartment blocks.\n\n\"It woke me up because the vibration of the sound was like a 747 coming in,\" said Kenneth Davis, an Israeli who was staying in a hotel opposite the struck building.\n\n\"And then the explosion... everything blew out in the room, the windows and things from the ceiling, and it was on me, nothing heavy, but lots of pieces of stuff,\" he told AFPTV.\n\nHagari said Israel \"intercepted another UAV trying to infiltrate from the east\" at around the same time as the Tel Aviv attack.\n\n\"We are investigating why the UAV was not identified as a threat and intercepted before it struck,\" he said. \"I want to emphasise that (Israel's air) defence is not impenetrable.\"\n\nMore from this section Home dubbed 'golfer's paradise' up for sale at $2M New Video Shows Trump's Head In Crosshairs; How Slight Head Tilt Saved Life: Report | US Election Most college students have little idea how government works, new survey shows\n\nIn recent weeks, the Islamic Resistance in Iraq, a loose alliance of Iran-backed groups, has claimed drone strikes against targets in Israel, labelling many of them \"joint operations\" with the Huthis.\n\nThe Gaza war began with the October 7 attack by Palestinian Hamas militants on Israel which resulted in the deaths of 1,195 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 42 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's military retaliation has killed at least 38,848 people, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in Hamas-ruled Gaza, where fighting raged on Friday.\n\n- 'Moral stain' -\n\nResidents said clashes were heard between Palestinian fighters and the Israeli army, with explosions and shelling in the Tal al-Hawa district of Gaza City.\n\nThe war has destroyed much of Gaza's housing and other infrastructure, leaving almost all the population displaced, short of food and drinking water.\n\nMany are living in unsanitary conditions. Health authorities in Gaza and Israel said on Thursday that highly infectious polio has been detected in Gaza sewage samples.\n\n\"The humanitarian situation... is a moral stain on us all,\" said UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has repeatedly insisted that, despite mounting pressure both at home and from abroad, there would be no let-up in Israel's campaign against Hamas.\n\nFar-right members of his governing coalition oppose a truce deal, including National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir who on Thursday said Netanyahu must not make a \"surrender\" accord with Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu is set to address the US Congress next Wednesday.\n\nThe White House said President Joe Biden was expected to meet with him, but it will depend on the US leader's recovery from Covid.\n\nAhead of Netanyahu's visit, Israeli lawmakers passed a symbolic resolution opposing the creation of a Palestinian state -- a move criticised by the United Nations and one that clashes with US ambitions for the region.\n\nDespite the Israeli vote, White House National Security Council spokesman John Kirby reiterated \"our firm belief in the power and the promise of the two-state solution.\"\n\nburs-dv/it", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": region, what is now called Israeli Tel Aviv,\" the statement said, adding that \"the operation has achieved its goals successfully\".\n\nThe Houthi announcement came after Israeli police reported a powerful explosion of unknown origin that went off in a building in Tel Aviv around 3am (1am Irish time).\n\nPolice said a search after the attack revealed one man \"dead in his apartment,\" bearing injuries caused by shrapnel.\n\nThe explosion left one person dead and two lightly injured, an Israeli emergency services spokesperson said.\n\nThe Magen David Adom emergency medical service said four people were taken to hospital with \"relatively minor\" injuries.\n\nThe Israeli army said the blast was \"caused by the falling of an aerial target\", according to an initial inquiry, and a military official later said a \"very big\" drone was responsible.\n\n\"No sirens were activated,\" the army said in a statement, adding that the air force had \"increased its air patrols in order to protect Israeli airspace\".\n\nThe Houthi rebels have launched dozens of drone and missile strikes targeting shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden since November in a campaign they say is intended to signal solidarity with Palestinians amid the Gaza war.\n\nThe Houthis have also alleged several attacks targeting the Israeli port city of Eilat, on the Gulf of Aqaba, but the strike is the first {"uri": "8234103610", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:20:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:20:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:19:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://americanmilitarynews.com/2024/07/houthis-claim-responsibility-for-deadly-tel-aviv-drone-strike/", "title": "Houthis Claim Responsibility For Deadly Tel Aviv Drone Strike", "body": "An explosive drone impacted inside Tel Aviv, Israel early on Friday morning, causing multiple casualties.\n\nThe Houthi faction in Yemen has claimed responsibility for the attack, which they said struck \"an important target\" in the area. The Israeli military said the drone struck a residential building in central Tel Aviv.\n\nIsrael Defense Forces (IDF) spokesman, Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, said the drone strike killed one civilian and injured eight more.\n\nHagari said the drone flew in from the west, coming in from over the sea. He said no alert was activated when the drone struck.\n\n\"We are investigating the incident, and checking why the UAV was not identified as a threat and was not intercepted before it hit,\" the Israeli spokesman said.\n\nHouthi military spokesman Yahya Sare'e said they used a new model of drone that's difficult to detect by radar and capable of avoiding interceptor systems.\n\nHagari said Israeli authorities believe the drone in question was an Iranian-designed Zimad 3 model modified to fly for extended periods of time.\n\nAt the same time the Houthi drone flew into Tel Aviv from the west, Hagari said Israeli air defenses detected and intercepted another drone coming in from the east.\n\nVideos posted to social media purported to show a view near where the drone impacted.\n\nThe Houthis are a primarily Shia Muslim faction and have fought with Yemen's predominantly Sunni Muslim government for years. A U.S.-backed Saudi Arabian-led coalition of Arab states intervened against the Houthis, but the rebel faction has persisted and now maintains control over a sizeable portion of the country, including the capital city of Sana'a.\n\nThe Yemeni civil war has largely died down in recent months with efforts to establish and maintain a lasting ceasefire in the country, but the Houthis turned their attention outward in October, to the ongoing fight between Israel and Hamas in the Gaza Strip. The Houthis have claimed solidarity with the Palestinians in the Gaza Strip and have launched drone and missile attacks from Yemen to disrupt Israel.\n\nMost of the Houthi attacks have targeted commercial ships in the Red Sea and its adjoining waterways. The Houthis have claimed to target ships connected to Israel or its allies and partners. But some attacks have also targeted Israeli cities, such as Eilat.\n\nThe drone strike comes as Israeli forces continue to battle in the Gaza Strip, and as they face an escalating conflict to their northern border, with Hezbollah.", "source": {"uri": "americanmilitarynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "American Military News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8233524697", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "12:46:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T12:46:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:45:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://therussophile.org/the-whole-building-shook-houthis-tel-aviv-drone-strike-kills-1-hospitalizes-8.html/", "title": "'The Whole Building Shook': Houthis' Tel Aviv Drone Strike Kills 1, Hospitalizes 8 - Russia News Now", "body": "In what could spark spiraling escalation of warfare between Yemen's Houthis, Hezbollah and the State of Israel, a large drone struck a high-rise building in central Tel Aviv overnight, killing 1 and wounding 8 more. Using social media, a Houthi spokesman indicated the group had launched a \"military operation\" that \"targeted 'Tel Aviv' in occupied Palestine'.\"\n\nSaudi-headquartered Al Arabiya reported that the Houthis fired four drones and a ballistic missile. The missile and three of the drones were said to have been shot down by US forces in the region. Witnesses say the 3:15 am blast was so loud, it was audible for miles. In video circulating on social media that purportedly captured the strike, a telltale buzzing sound is heard followed by a blinding flash and the sound of an explosion:\n\n\"The whole building shook,\" Alon, a local resident, told Haaretz. \"My neighbours' windows shattered so I was sure something had hit the building. It was only when I went outside that I realized that several buildings had been damaged.\" According to one report, eight victims were hospitalized; four were wounded, while the others were receiving treatment \"for anxiety.\"\n\nNo alarms were sounded. This latest Israel Defense Forces (IDF) failure promises to heighten Israelis' sense of vulnerability that persists nine months after the stunning Oct. 7 Hamas invasion of southern Israel. Following the attack, the IDF said it had elevated air patrols to bolster defenses. While it wasn't struck, a branch office of the US embassy was described as just 100 meters away from the blast. (For perspective, that's even closer than the distance between former President Trump and the sniper perched on a gently-sloping but mostly-dangerous roof in Butler, Pennsylvania.)\n\nWhile ZeroHedge can't confirm their authenticity, these videos circulating on social media are said to show an aerial view of an enormous fireball, and the ensuing smokey chaos in the streets:\n\nA paramedic who was among the first to respond to the attack told Haaretz that he treated two wounded people in the street, and two more who were in their residences in the building. \"Shortly [after that], we found the fatality on one of the top floors of an adjacent building. He was in bed and there was shrapnel damage everywhere in his apartment.\"\n\nHours after the attack, a Houthi spokesman used a televised speech to declare that Tel Aviv would continue to be a principal target \"within the range of our weapons.\" He touted a new drone called \"Yafa\" -- presumably named after the Jaffa region of Israel where Tel Aviv is located. \"It is capable of bypassing interception systems and radars cannot detect it,\" the Houthis claimed in an accompanying tweet. Tel Aviv is some 1,200 miles from Yemen.\n\nAlong with the Lebanese Hezbollah militia, Yemen's Houthis have been waging war on Israel and Israel-linked cargo ships, in solidarity with millions of Palestinians suffering under the effects of the IDF's devastating military attacks and blockade on Gaza that began after the Oct. 7 Hamas invasion.\n\nFriday morning's attack on Tel Aviv came hours after the IDF claimed it had killed a senior commander of the Lebanese Hezbollah militia, which has been increasingly aggressive in striking targets across northern Israel and the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights. That commander, Ali Jaafar Maatouk, was said to have died when an IDF fighter-jet strike obliterated the three-story house he was in:\n\nWatch for a significant IDF retaliation for the Tel Aviv strike, which could, in turn, invite even more ambitious aggression by the forces arrayed against the State of Israel.\n\nWe must add Houthis did warn about expanding their threat coverage to the Mediterranean area in May (read: here).\n\n\"Between hitting a tanker carrying Russian oil and their latest attack inside Israel, the Houthis are overextending themselves and will soon feel the pain of real firepower as Israel looks beyond Gaza and Lebanon and the US, potentially under Trump, gets tougher on Iran and its proxies,\" said Scott Modell, who heads Rapidan Energy Group.", "source": {"uri": "8233599969", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "13:37:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T13:37:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T13:36:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.spacewar.com/afp/240719131326.93od3us8.html", "title": "One dead as Huthi-claimed drone breaches Israel defences", "body": "The Huthis fired at Tel Aviv a \"new drone called 'Yafa', which is capable of bypassing the enemy's interception systems,\" said Yahya Saree, the Iran-backed Yemeni movement's spokesman.\n\nThe Huthis have targeted shipping in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden with numerous drone and missile attacks since November, citing solidarity with Palestinians during the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza.\n\nThey have previously claimed attacks on Israeli cities including Ashdod, Haifa and Eilat, but Friday's strike appears to be the first to breach Israel's intricate air defences.\n\nIt comes after the rebels threatened an escalation.\n\nAn Israeli military official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a \"very big drone that can travel long distances\" was used in the 3:12 am (0012 GMT) attack.\n\nThe drone was detected, he said, but due to \"human error\" the alarm was not raised in time, and it slammed into an apartment building.\n\nMilitary spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said Israel believed the drone used was Iranian-made and upgraded so it could reach Tel Aviv from Yemen -- at least 1,800 kilometres (1,100 miles) away.\n\nIt was \"likely a Samad-3 model, which we estimate was launched from Yemen and reached Tel Aviv,\" he said, adding one civilian was killed and others lightly injured. Medical services said four people suffered \"relatively minor\" injuries.\n\nIsraeli Defence Minister Yoav Gallant vowed to avenge the drone attack.\n\n\"The security system will settle the score with all who try to harm the state of Israel, or sends terrorism against it, in a decisive and surprising manner,\" he said in comments released on social media platform X.\n\nIn grainy security camera footage, the buzz of what appeared to be the drone was followed by an explosion that shook the building and set off car alarms.\n\nThe blast occurred about 100 metres (yards) from a US embassy annex, said an AFP journalist who saw broken windows along the street lined with apartment blocks.\n\n\"It woke me up because the vibration of the sound was like a 747 coming in,\" said Kenneth Davis, an Israeli who was staying in a hotel opposite the struck building.\n\n\"And then the explosion... everything blew out in the room, the windows and things from the ceiling, and it was on me, nothing heavy, but lots of pieces of stuff,\" he told AFPTV.\n\nHagari said Israel \"intercepted another UAV trying to infiltrate from the east\" at around the same time as the Tel Aviv attack.\n\n\"We are investigating why the UAV was not identified as a threat and intercepted before it struck,\" he said. \"I want to emphasise that (Israel's air) defence is not impenetrable.\"\n\nIn recent weeks, the Islamic Resistance in Iraq, a loose alliance of Iran-backed groups, has claimed drone strikes against targets in Israel, labelling many of them \"joint operations\" with the Huthis.\n\nThe United States and Britain launched a campaign of air strikes in January to deter Huthi attacks on ships.\n\nThe Gaza war was triggered by the October 7 attack by Palestinian Hamas militants on southern Israel which resulted in the deaths of 1,195 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 42 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's military retaliation to wipe out Hamas has killed at least 38,848 people, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in Hamas-ruled Gaza, where fighting raged on Friday.\n\nResidents said clashes were heard between Palestinian fighters and the Israeli army, with explosions and shelling in the Tal al-Hawa district of Gaza City.\n\nThe war has destroyed much of Gaza's housing and other infrastructure, leaving almost all the population displaced, short of food and drinking water.\n\nMany are living in unsanitary conditions. Health authorities in Gaza and Israel said on Thursday that a highly infectious polio virus has been detected in Gaza sewage samples.\n\nThe World Health Organization said on Friday however that so far no cases of polio had been discovered in Gaza.\n\n\"The humanitarian situation... is a moral stain on us all,\" said UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has repeatedly insisted that, despite mounting pressure both at home and from abroad, there would be no let-up in Israel's campaign against Hamas.\n\nFar-right members of his governing coalition oppose a truce deal, including National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir who on Thursday said Netanyahu must not make a \"surrender\" accord with Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu is set to address the US Congress next Wednesday.\n\nAhead of his trip, Israeli lawmakers passed a symbolic resolution opposing the creation of a Palestinian state -- a move criticised by the United Nations and one that clashes with US ambitions for the region.\n\nDespite the vote, White House National Security Council spokesman John Kirby reiterated \"our firm belief in the power and the promise of the two-state {"uri": "2024-07-427480003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "18:28:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T18:28:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:45:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/israel-threatens-reprisals-for-deadly-yemen-rebel-drone-strike/article_d6fd6f47-440c-5a5d-a31c-86be7830e2b3.html", "title": "Israel threatens reprisals for deadly Yemen rebel drone strike", "body": "Yemeni students chant anti-Israeli and anti-US slogans at a protest against the Gaza war in the rebel-held capital Sanaa on Wednesday\n\nIsrael threatened reprisals Friday after a drone claimed by Yemen's Huthi rebels penetrated its vaunted air defences and killed a civilian in a Tel Aviv apartment building near a US embassy annexe.\n\nThe attack drew condemnation from UN chief Antonio Guterres and an appeal for \"maximum restraint\" to avoid \"further escalation in the region\".\n\nThe pre-dawn strike came hours before Israel suffered another blow, a ruling by the UN's top court that its occupation of the Palestinian territories was \"illegal\" and needed to end as soon as possible.\n\nThe advisory opinion of The Hague-based International Court of Justice is not binding, but it comes amid mounting international condemnation of Israel's handling of its war on Hamas in Gaza.\n\nThe office of Palestinian president Manmud Abbas hailed the court's decision as \"a victory for justice\".\n\nBut Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has overseen a major expansion of Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, insisted: \"The Jewish people are not occupiers in their own land.\"\n\nThe Huthis are one of a number of Iran-backed armed groups around the Middle East that have claimed drone and missile attacks on Israel in retaliation for the Gaza war.\n\nThey have previously claimed attacks on Israeli cities including Ashdod, Haifa and Eilat, but Friday's strike appears to be the first to breach Israel's sophisticated air defences.\n\nThe Huthis fired at Tel Aviv a \"new drone called 'Yafa', which is capable of bypassing the enemy's interception systems\", their spokesman Yahya Saree said.\n\nAn Israeli military official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a \"very big drone that can travel long distances\" was used in the 3:12 am (0012 GMT) attack.\n\nHe said the drone was detected but due to \"human error\" the alarm was not raised in time, and it slammed into an apartment building.\n\nMilitary spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said Israel believed the drone used was Iranian-made and upgraded so it could reach Tel Aviv from Yemen -- at least 1,800 kilometres (1,100 miles) away.\n\nIt was \"likely a Samad-3 model, which we estimate was launched from Yemen and reached Tel Aviv,\" he said, adding one civilian was killed and others lightly injured. Medical services said four people suffered \"relatively minor\" injuries.\n\nDefence Minister Yoav Gallant vowed to avenge the drone attack.\n\n\"The security system will settle the score with all who try to harm the state of Israel, or sends terrorism against it, in a decisive and surprising manner,\" he said in comments posted on social media platform X.\n\n- 'Everything blew out' -\n\nIn grainy security camera footage, the buzz of what appeared to be the drone was followed by an explosion that shook the building and set off car alarms.\n\nThe blast occurred about 100 metres (300 feet) from a US embassy annexe, said an AFP journalist who saw broken windows along the street lined with apartment blocks.\n\n\"It woke me up because the vibration of the sound was like a 747 (jet) coming in,\" said Kenneth Davis, an Israeli who was staying in a hotel opposite the building which was hit.\n\n\"And then the explosion... everything blew out in the room,\" he told AFPTV.\n\nHagari said Israel \"intercepted another UAV trying to infiltrate from the east\" at around the same time as the Tel Aviv attack.\n\n\"We are investigating why the UAV was not identified as a threat and intercepted before it struck,\" he said.\n\nIn recent weeks, the Islamic Resistance in Iraq, a loose alliance of Iran-backed groups, has claimed drone strikes against targets in Israel, labelling many of them \"joint operations\" with the Huthis.\n\nSince November, the Huthis have also carried out dozens of drone and missile attacks on shipping in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden that they claim is Israeli-linked.\n\nThe United States and Britain launched a campaign of air strikes in January to deter the attacks on merchant vessels.\n\nThe Gaza war was triggered by Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel which resulted in the deaths of 1,195 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 42 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory campaign has killed at least 38,848 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory, where fighting raged on Friday.\n\n- WHO reports no polio cases -\n\nResidents said clashes were heard between Palestinian fighters and the Israeli army, with explosions and shelling in the Tal al-Hawa district of Gaza City.\n\nThe war has destroyed much of Gaza's housing and other infrastructure, leaving virtually the entire population displaced and short of food and drinking water.\n\nMany are living in unsanitary conditions. Health authorities in Gaza and Israel said on Thursday that poliovirus had been detected in Gaza sewage samples.\n\nThe World Health Organization said on Friday that no cases of the highly infectious disease had been discovered in Gaza so far.\n\nburs-dv/jkb/kir\n\nMore from this section\n\nModern Foot & Ankle Expands Reconstructive Surgery Services in Celebration, Winter Garden with New Podiatrist\n\nWilliam Cole Vineyards Celebrates the 25th Anniversary of Cuv\u00e9e Claire\n\nSen. "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/one-dead-as-huthi-claimed-drone-breaches-israel-defences/article_d6fd6f47-440c-5a5d-a31c-86be7830e2b3.html", "title": "One dead as Huthi-claimed drone breaches Israel defences", "body": "A Palestinian boy walks through heaps of garbage at a camp for displaced people in Khan Yunis, southern Gaza -- many are living in unsanitary conditions\n\nA drone claimed by Yemen's Huthi rebels slipped through Israel's vaunted air defence system on Friday to hit a Tel Aviv building near a US embassy annex, killing a civilian.\n\nThe Huthis fired at Tel Aviv a \"new drone called 'Yafa', which is capable of bypassing the enemy's interception systems,\" said Yahya Saree, the Iran-backed Yemeni movement's spokesman.\n\nThe Huthis have targeted shipping in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden with numerous drone and missile attacks since November, citing solidarity with Palestinians during the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza.\n\nThey have previously claimed attacks on Israeli cities including Ashdod, Haifa and Eilat, but Friday's strike appears to be the first to breach Israel's intricate air defences.\n\nIt comes after they threatened an escalation.\n\nAn Israeli military official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a \"very big drone that can travel long distances\" was used in the attack which killed one person and occurred at 3:12 am (0012 GMT).\n\nThe drone was detected, the official said, but due to \"human error\" the alarm was not raised in time, and it slammed into an apartment building.\n\nMilitary spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said Israel believed the drone the drone used was Iranian-made and upgraded so that it could reach Tel Aviv from Yemen -- at least 1,800 kilometres (1,100 miles) away.\n\nIt was \"likely a Samad-3 model, which we estimate was launched from Yemen and reached Tel Aviv,\" he said, adding the impact killed one civilian and lightly injured others.\n\nEmergency medical services said four people were taken to hospital with \"relatively minor\" injuries.\n\n- 'Everything blew out' -\n\nIn grainy security camera footage, the buzz of what appeared to be the drone was followed by an explosion that shook the building and set off car alarms.\n\nThe blast occurred about 100 metres (yards) from a US embassy annex, said an AFP journalist who saw broken windows along the street lined with apartment blocks.\n\n\"It woke me up because the vibration of the sound was like a 747 coming in,\" said Kenneth Davis, an Israeli who was staying in a hotel opposite the struck building.\n\n\"And then the explosion... everything blew out in the room, the windows and things from the ceiling, and it was on me, nothing heavy, but lots of pieces of stuff,\" he told AFPTV.\n\nHagari said Israel \"intercepted another UAV trying to infiltrate from the east\" at around the same time as the Tel Aviv attack.\n\n\"We are investigating why the UAV was not identified as a threat and intercepted before it struck,\" he said. \"I want to emphasise that (Israel's air) defence is not impenetrable.\"\n\nIn recent weeks, the Islamic Resistance in Iraq, a loose alliance of Iran-backed groups, has claimed drone strikes against targets in Israel, labelling many of them \"joint operations\" with the Huthis.\n\nThe Gaza war began with the October 7 attack by Palestinian Hamas militants on Israel which resulted in the deaths of 1,195 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 42 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's military retaliation has killed at least 38,848 people, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in Hamas-ruled Gaza, where fighting raged on Friday.\n\n- 'Moral stain' -\n\nResidents said clashes were heard between Palestinian fighters and the Israeli army, with explosions and shelling in the Tal al-Hawa district of Gaza City.\n\nThe war has destroyed much of Gaza's housing and other infrastructure, leaving almost all the population displaced, short of food and drinking water.\n\nMany are living in unsanitary conditions. Health authorities in Gaza and Israel said on Thursday that highly infectious polio has been detected in Gaza sewage samples.\n\n\"The humanitarian situation... is a moral stain on us all,\" said UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has repeatedly insisted that, despite mounting pressure both at home and from abroad, there would be no let-up in Israel's campaign against Hamas.\n\nFar-right members of his governing coalition oppose a truce deal, including National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir who on Thursday said Netanyahu must not make a \"surrender\" accord with Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu is set to address the US Congress next Wednesday.\n\nThe White House said President Joe Biden was expected to meet with him, but it will depend on the US leader's recovery from Covid.\n\nAhead of Netanyahu's visit, Israeli lawmakers passed a symbolic resolution opposing the creation of a Palestinian state -- a move criticised by the United Nations and one that clashes with US ambitions for the region.\n\nDespite the Israeli vote, White House National Security Council spokesman John Kirby reiterated \"our firm belief in the power and the promise of the two-state solution.\"\n\nburs-dv/it\n\nMore from this section\n\nSen. Israeli sources indicated a potential response in Yemen.\n\nThe Alma Research Center identified the drone as a KAS-04 model, equipped with 40 kilograms of explosives. Launched from Yemen, it traveled nearly 2,000 kilometers, with reduced explosives to allow for increased fuel capacity.\n\nIsraeli military spokesperson Daniel Hagari confirmed that the drone was an Iranian-made Samad-3 model, striking a building near the US Embassy in Tel Aviv. \"Our assessments indicate the drone flew from Yemen to Tel Aviv,\" Hagari stated at a press conference.\n\nThe Houthis have repeatedly launched drones and missiles towards Israel and at Israeli-linked shipping in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden in a show of support for Palestinians amid Israel's war on Gaza.\n\nUntil the early morning attack on Friday, all attempts to hit Israel by the Houthis were intercepted by either Israeli defences or Western allies with forces stationed in the region, The Associated Press Israel's war on Gaza, which has killed almost 39,000 people.\n\nFollowing the latest drone attack, Hezbollah welcomed the development as \"a triumph for the oppression of the Palestinian people and The incident is under review,\" the military said in a brief statement.\n\nNo aerial sirens were reported prior to the blast, which occurred hours after the Israeli military confirmed it had killed a senior commander of the Iran-backed Hezbollah militia in southern Lebanon.\n\nThe blast occurred just meters away from the U.S. Embassy building in Tel Aviv.\n\nTel Aviv Police District Commander Peretz Amar said that it is still unclear what caused the explosion in central Tel Aviv at 3:15 A.M. on Friday.\n\n\"The blast apparently occurred at some altitude,\" Amar said. \"We still do not know what it was.
